reviewText: Papa & Yo is an amazing indiegame. It's colourful, creative, original and cute, and at the same time it's sad as hell. A true indie game. It's a bit short though and it seems a little expensive to buy it for 13 euros on steam... You can wait for it to get on sale if you want - but you have to play it sooner or later! There are a few bugs and glitches, but nothing major. It doesn't ruin the whole experience - and this game is definetly an experience! The graphics are good/fine, the music is good and calm and well-fitting, the story is short but very good and... this is just a great game - i strongly reccomend it. :-)

Man, the final chapter...... I've got surprised. There's a deep meaning to every character you see. A story behing on what you are facing in the game.

This game is great. It's beaultiful, it's gorgeous, it's brilliant. At first, you think this game is just a simple and bealtiful game, but after the end, you may see a diferent perception of it. The puzzles are great and challenging. You always have a little hint if you need and it's incredibly fun to solve it ( even when you have to control the monster to not eat the freakin frog. God, that was annoying.... but fun ).
I've never seen a game like that. It's just bealtiful, but as long as you keep playing, getting closer and closer to the end... the game becames darker and a bit deep. I don't think someone 'simple-minded' could handle the truth.

I've got really touched at the credits. The music was just so...... I don't know what to say. It was a nice experience and definetly worth the money. But the end, the credits....... oh god.......

This game is about a father and son illustrated with Monster and kids

- Kinda short

= 8.5/10 from me

A short, but touching story about the struggles of a kid to get away from his abusive father. Though the whole game is very easy and I could play it with my low-end Pc at high graphics, I still think it was a beautiful experience and I enjoied every minute of it. On the one side, those 4 hours weren't very much, but on the other I definitly think this is the better way of making games: If you don't have anything more to mention, just end it and let the gamer remember all the fun parts instead of repeating the same things over and over again and strech the game for profit. I liked the graphics and the music, but 13‚Ç¨ is a bit high for just like a little story. Because the game is not about anything else than the characters and the story and Quichos amazing fantasy. If anyone struggles to buy this game just wait until it's in a promotion for about 5‚Ç¨ or less. This is the price, I would definitly give this team for their production!

Papo & Yo, as an indie 3D puzzle platformer, succeeds in providing an experience so adventurous yet so calming. One of the strongest points of this game is the beautiful and ambient soundtrack that accompanies the game's storyline; on the outside, it appears to simply be an adventure/fantasy puzzle-solving game but on the inside, it holds much more as the subtle and beautifully laid out overarching background story fills in the cavities of why the protagonist, the boy, Quico is running around seeking a fantasised asylum. With beautiful visuals and relatively smooth controls, the only and main problem that Papo & Yo suffers from (within personal experience) is the frame-rate drops and lag that occurs quite a bit throughout the game. 9/10
Highly recommended.

Neat Indie game with an interesting back story. I bought it on sale for around 1 dollar, not the 15 that it normally is. Short story; I finished in about 3 hours. Also, the puzzles aren't very difficult at all. If you're going to play it, play it for it's artistic value-not gameplay.

This game is quite beautiful and also heartbreaking. The game actually makes the player feel the frustration and hopelessness of dealing with an alcoholic family member, while still loving them and wanting to be with them. During the first playthrough I was worried that the game would suggest to young kids that they were responsible or capable of changing their alcoholic parents, but the ending convinced me otherwise. Well done.

An adventure/puzzle-platformer that's light on challenge but heavy on quality story-telling. Excellent presentation and beautiful Latin American-themed artwork/music make Papo & Yo both a visual and audible pleasure. While the puzzles aren't anything that'll test your mind, it's less about figuring out how to solve them and more about watching and admiring the solutions as they unfold. The way you can manipulate the world with the push or pull of a lever is a neat sight to behold and has a child-like imagination" feel to it. There are a few technical issues present (noticeable framerate drops here and there)
recommended: an impressive game that does a great job of using metaphors and symbolism to tell a powerful story full of dark subject matter in an accessible manner. Short

I had read IGN's review of the fantastic Papo & Yo prior to playing, and I have to say; how wrong is Mitch Dyer? It's seems like he didn't have the patience for the simple puzzles and complained too much about the too few bugs, which were minscule.

And then I read Kotaku's review, and it was spot on: This game is a must play. It's imaginative, graphically impressive, the narrative is strong, the gameplay is simple enough. There's not too much wrong with the game. In fact, the only thing wrong with it might be some PC optimization, but lowering the settings a bit fixes that.

It was clear what the story was going to be about from the opening message and intro scene from the creative director and writer, a story about a boy with an abusive, alcoholic father. It's heartfelt and means well, but wasn't as inspired or hidden like how the masterpiece, Braid, shocks you at the end.

The game acts as a puzzler/adventure with platforming mechanics, jumping and stuff. It's done well, but a bit on the easier side. The puzzles were....simple, I guess is the best way of putting it. But it came with enjoyment, which Mitch Dyer didn't find it to be. The soundtrack and audio design is well done, I mean really well done. I was in awe of the composition and layering of instruments. Animation was fantastic, as expected; animators in Montreal do tend to put extra effort in their work. The graphics are visually impressive, great texturing, modeling, lighting, the favelas of Brazil are a great sight and I wish I could have seen more. But when the game starts to get more fantastical, the favelas become less important. The magical houses were sweet though. Also, fantastic lighting and shadowing.

I don't know what else to say, the game is great. Check it out.

9.0/10
Again a great example, how much more games can be. Hit me more than Brothers"..."

reviewText:
Papo and Yo is well worth your time.

Very novel, well executed and powerful subject matter. Papo and Yo is the culimination of a son's experiences with his drunken and abusive father.

Dark stuff indeed, but Papo and Yo is very careful not to overplay its theme too hard.

The game felt to me as if it were borrowing from Miyazaki's Spirited Away at times. A young protagonist trying to cope with circumstances far outside their control. Dark at times, but careful to not to burn you out, feeding you just a small piece of the darker story before dropping you back into lighter fantasy.

The game features a lot of thought and consideration for the design of it's puzzles and mechanics. The platform elements are rarely frustrating. And, the game provides many shortcuts as you explore a given level to help you recover from bad jumps.

This game is just a great bit of fun and has great payoff of its theme. Please give this one a play.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Mechanically this game is nothing special. But I love it. Its what I would deem a game that pushes the medium forward as a story teller and as a catalyst for change. It does this on multiple levels.

1. This tells a meaningful and emotional story without having the main charcater wield a gun or act violent.
2. The main charcater is not white or tasked with saving humanity (Not that these types of games are bad, its just they represent 99% of games)

This is story about a childs at first inability and then learning to overcome his alcoholic and abusive father (I wouldn't consideer that a spoiler, its obvious from the get go that these characters and ideas were metaphors) And you don't play this to find that out anyways, you play it because rather than like a book or movie passively consuming a story. You are actively pursuing its conclusion. In a way your helping the child overcome his fears and distorted memories. That level of interaction with a story can't be obtained by any other medium and that's what makes the story so much more impactful.

reviewText:
A beautiful and heart-wrenching game entrenched in metaphor. This game left me shocked, silent and with a lot of thoughts to process. Our story opens with Quico, a young boy living in a Brazillin favela with his abusive alcoholic father. Retreating into his imagination, we follow his adventures through a surreal landscape as he interacts with his friend Monster as his means of coping with the real world. Beautifully written and and powerfully executed, more than once I felt on the brink of being physically ill at many of the implications and how they related to Quico's life.

In terms of gameplay, it's a fairly standard puzzle-platformer. As you travel through the favela you'll be pulling levers, hitting buttons, manipulating the landscape in surreal ways, and either coaxing Monster to aid you, or running from him. The puzzles are fairly simple and never frustrating, nor do they ever interfere with the game's atmosphere. In terms of music, the atmosphere is only boosted by a gorgeous soundtrack (which you can purchase along with the game). The game's only downfall is how short it is, as it can be completed in less than a day.

This is truly a masterpiece and a work of art. If you're a fan of heavily story-driven games, I highly recommend Papo & Yo.

reviewText: This may very well be the first example of magic realism in a videogame. More than a little rough around the edges, Papo & Yo still deserves enormous respect for its brilliant handling of metaphor, unerring focus on the strengths of the medium and other fancy concepts like that while managing to not be too snobbish and arty-wanky about it. Add painterly, enchanting visuals and culture-fusing music to that and you've got something quite unique on your hands.

reviewText:
I really wanted to be able to recommend this game, even if only as an experience. It ticks all the boxes I look for in an interesting game - It‚Äôs developed in a country not known for their dev studios, it discusses a very real and very important question and it‚Äôs technically well executed.

But I can‚Äôt recommend it as it makes the cardinal error for an interactive experience - it‚Äôs plain boring. The theme of parental abuse is overstated and the metaphors crude, but all that could be forgiven if it was only fun to play. As it stands it‚Äôs a run-of-the-mill 3d puzzle platformer with unimaginative puzzles with no story telling.

Should be played by hardcore explorers of the modern gaming medium due to the reasons in the first paragraph or if you need to write about it. Otherwise stay away.

reviewText:
Papo & Yo is a truly excellent 3d puzzle platformer has great gameplay, great visuals, and a great story.

The main gameplay sees you solving a series of puzzles using what's given to you by the environment. Each puzzle introduces some kind of mechanic and the 3D platforming gameplay gives you an interface to interact with that mechanic. Discovering what that mechanic does then figuring out how to manipulate it to progress is key and the game does an excellent job of letting you explore the mechanics without punishing you for trying something that doesn't work.  If you mess up, the game gives you a way to come back from what you've done and in the few cases where you can fail (such as falling off a cliff), you get put back in quickly so you can try again. This is a great way to encourage players to explore their options and try anything they can think of and is an example of how to do puzzles well. None of the puzzles are repeats, so each puzzle gives you something new to chew on without any filler. All of the challenges are really well designed and fun, while there were one or two puzzles that got a bit tedious, I wouldn't say any of them were unenjoyable. I did encounter one glitch where my character got stuck and couldn't move, but other than that everything was pretty solid.

The graphics of this game are excellent both artistically and technically. Unreal Engine 3 is being used in full force to create a game that looks nothing short of gorgeous. The game uses lighting and bump mapping to great effect, but this would be mean nothing without the creative visuals that the developers put on display. The game more or less take place inside the protagonist's imagination (that's not a spoiler by the way), so they get really creative with the environments. The color pallete is vibrant and absolutely beautiful to look at. The animation of the monster is also fantastic, although the player character's run cycle felt a little bit stiff.

Unlike most indie games that run on Unreal Engine 3, this game is actually extremely well optimized, and my GT 440 (which is somewhat old and outdated by now) usually got around 40 FPS on max settings.

Even though the gameplay and graphics are fantastic, the story just might be the best thing about Papo & Yo. I won't go into too much detail because that would spoil it, but the storytelling does a great job of telling a deep, emotional story in a mostly nonverbal way. What you see in the imaginary world of the character's imagination is allegorical to his life (and the life of the creator of the game), which makes the game feel the developer is opening up a very personal part of his life to you. It's emotional and beautiful there are some soulcrushing twists along the way.

Overall, Papo & Yo is a must-play for anyone interested in puzzle games or great stories.

reviewText:
Papo & Yo is Puzzle Plattformer. Through the game you will meet a monster and while he seem like a great big friend, who jeats and sleeps a lot. He has an addiction for poisonous frogs, your goal is to cure this addiction and guide the monster through the weird world you're in. The story gets more indepth as you progress further, things get weird and out of control, with an really good conclusion.
As for the Gameplay, while there are a lot of switches, they only add up to unique, interesting, but easy levels, with some reused gimmics while most being used only once. Pressing switches is tied into the Plattforming, you'll be either getting a switch to get a plattform and get to other switches. The puzzles‚Äô while simple are mixed up and the plattforming only has a jump/double jump.
Overall simple, but interesting gameplay, which turns into 'a journey' to cure your big 'friend' monster.
This gets a G for GOOD (A>G>O)

Note: Shout out to postuumi for gifting me this game, I regret that I took so long to start playing it.

reviewText:
The game starts out a bit slow but give it a go for at least 30 minutes and you'll start to see what got me hooked. This is probably one of the very few games I'll tell players to FINISH IT. PLAY IT TILL THE END.

The game is short compared to other story driven games but you know what? It might be short but time well spent. Story telling in this game is subtle - it doesn't make any sense in the beginning but slowly everything will come together as you play. No plot twist, story just unfolds gradually and then BAM! Everything make sense at the end.

The puzzle difficulty is just right for me, a couple of retries here and there but not to the point of throwing away my gamepad and bawling on the couch. Even if you're not the puzzle type of person, go play around with the puzzle and you'll be at awe at some of the designs. Manipulating buildings, terrain and my favourite - carrying big fat squishy frogs (I don't think anyone enjoy splatting the frogs though, they're too cute to be treated that way!)

Another thing that's worth praising are the the tutorial and hint system are very well done - unobstructive upon request-only tutorial and subtle hints pointing you to the right direction without giving it all.

If you're looking for a short, but meaningful game - this is the one.

reviewText:
An incredibly rewarding work of art.

If you stop reading reviews and go into Papo y Yo knowing as little as possible, you'll spend your first hour or so of gameplay not knowing what the hell is going on.  Hopefully, like me, you'll won't care at all because it's some of the most clever and inventive platforming gameplay I've seen in years.

Little by little the symbolism in the game will start creeping though and you begin to realize exactly what is happeng to the main character, Quico. You start seeing what all the tiny pieces that make up this adventure really are to our hero.  Before you know it Papo y Yo is punching you in the feels.

It's not the saddest storyline I've seen in gaming, but it's presented in such a beautful way that I couldn't help but shed a few tears once the credit's were rolling.  I can't recommend this game enough.  10/10.

But that would leave out the fact that this is an incredibly moving and touching game. It deals with a very serious and personal issue of the game creator's childhood and transforms it into a heartfelt game as a sort of personal therapy. The ending is specially cathartic. A must buy if you want to take a look at what games can do when they go beyond the usual thematic conventions of gaming.

reviewText:
Papo & Yo ('Father & I') is a third person puzzle platformer and tells the story of Quico and his friend Monster, who has a prefernce for tasty frogs. Unfortunately, these frogs turn the calm Monster into a violent and dangerous creature, so Quico sets out to find a cure for his friend - but is there any?

While this sounds like your average game story, it gains a lot of emotion and intensity once you realize that the story is metaphorical for Creative Director Vander Caballero's troubled childhood. It's relatively subtly tied into the game and if you don't pay enough attention or don't care about it, you could very well miss the message of the game, so don't rush it, step back for a moment and let the impressions work.

The game has relatively simple platforming mechanics and you will mostly end up jumping over gaps to progress in the level. Due the general pace of the game, there hardly are any timed events where, for example, you have to press a button and then quickly run somewhere to move on.

Relatively early into the game you also find your friend Lula, a toy robot who will latch onto your back and lets you double jump by launching his tiny jet pack. Additionally, you can also command him to flip switches that are out of your reach.

While the puzzles present themselves in a unique and creative manner, they aren't really challenging at all and mostly just require simple combination skills. It's a shame because the puzzle design as such is wonderful and could've made for some fun challenges.

Papo & Yo is based on the Unreal 3 Engine and while this engine isn't exactly the standard for visual fidelity these days, the game still looks pretty good and the lighting and level design add a lot to the overall atmosphere.

With roughly 4 hours of playtime, the game is fairly short, but if the game would've been filled with repetative puzzles in favor of playtime, the emotion and strength of the story would have suffered immensively and would've made this game just yet another average puzzle platformer.

There are dolls scattered throughout the levels and once you beat the game, those dolls will receive hats which you then can collect in a second playthrough. Other than that, the game doesn't provide you with anything else to do, which is fine - games like Papo & Yo aren't meant to be played for days, weeks or months. They want you to immerse yourself for a few hours, tell you a story and maybe even think about it a few days later.

Papo & Yo is a prime example of how emotional and intense video games can be. Don't buy it for the platforming and don't buy it for the puzzles. Buy it for the story and let the emotions take over.

reviewText:
Papo & Yo is a 3D puzzle platformer that has great art, great concept and a moving story but suffers from clunky controls, lack of invention in the puzzles and some minor glitches.
7/10

The game tells a story of a troubled boy through a fantasy setting in a Brazilian favela. While the idea is great, the potential is not fulfilled since the way the story is presented fails to make you really identify and care for the boy. It has some fantastic moments but it feels like the creator lost some immersion in an effort to avoid making it depressing.
The puzzles are not hard and the resulting animations are great but all of them feel like a variation on the same puzzle. The platforming part is not hard either but the controls are definitely lacking. It is not accurate in movement and in depth causing you to miss simple jumps and redoing the part again.
The art style is really great. The scenes are beautiful and deliver wonderfully the favela feeling, especially the wall drawings. The characters are inventive and well animated and the subtle graphical effects really enhance the magical felling of the game.

I really liked the different direction this game is taking and I would very much like to see another title from this developer - hopefully with more attitude to the story and improvement to the technical side. Took me about 5 hours to complete the game.

reviewText:
Papo and Yo originally invented for the PS3 is renowned for it's role as an empathy game. One of the few games on the market aimed specifically to evoke an emotional empathy response from it's player, this is largely because the developer Vander Caballero found here... http://www.weareminority.com/ has decided to use the expression of game art to exercise his own personal demons.

While it was largely inspired by the game 'ICO' there is a more larger similarity to the game 'Among the Sleep' and 'Brothers' in the way that the developer has chose to use cute characters and backgrounds to handle some adult touchy subjects such as alcoholism and physical abuse.

The story revolves around a young Brazillian boy named Quico who cowers in his bedroom closet while his father storms past. He then escapes into a magical slum world he creates where he finds a girl Alejandra who at first sees Quico as a threat, but who eventually aids him in his adventure. He is also joined by a robot toy named 'Lulu' which always has his back and a monster who is usually somewhat love-able who sleeps a lot and you can have fun bouncing off his belly, but when he ever has French Cuisine he launches himself into a rampaging devil. All set out on a magical journey which ends both bitter and sweet.

The amazing slum background which would have Salvador Dali jumping up and down on a cat in excitement is sheer magical and enchanting to explore. While the puzzles aren't that sophisticated, some can be challenging on the basis that they are slightly vague and will have you scurrying either for a hint box placed in the game which you can don on and run around in or for a youtube walk through. In truth you've probably just missed something obvious like the fact that you can move the buttons as well as press them.

Your first run through will be greeted with a metaphor of what happened in the developers personal life, you will also be challenged to go through the entire game a second time, this time without the need of a hint box and the further realization that 25 collectible hats have been hidden in the game.

So what are the metaphors in the game? Unlike other games which often be coy about the matter and leave it open the gamer's digression. The developer here wants his story to be told. (Spoiler Alert) The developer (quico) grew up with an abusive father (monster) who was an alcoholic due to the fact that he had accidentally hit someone in his car and killed them. The developer's mother (lulu) always was there for Quico until one day when the monster seemed to have killed lulu (severe abuse) eventually she did get better though through the help of Alejandra (a mixture of the developers first love and his literal little brother) .They at first tried reasoning and hiding the frogs (alcohol) which was making the monster angry. But after one severe abusive bout which took the life of Alejandro Quico eventually realises that he cannot cure this monster and instead has to let this monster go from his life for good. As Quico grows up he drifts away from his dependance of Lulu and pushes the monster away from his life for good after what he witnesses with his attack on Alejandro.

The game is well made, because the puzzles aren't that difficult no severe feeling of accomplishment is ever made and so the moral of the story is some what less victorious in feeling. The monster in the game just tosses you about too and is not really that fearing enough to make you sympathise as much as you do in 'Among the Sleep'. The biggest enemy of the game though is it's price. With such a noble meaning and story to a game you would think that they would lower the price so that more could enjoy as the game is also hardly long enough to warrant a large sum. However it should be noted that making games can be a very expensive journey. When asked why he chose frogs to represent bottles of alcohol, the developer replied that it was largely to do with cost. They originally wanted chickens to represent bottles of alcohol in the game, but to put chickens in the game would have cost them $15,000. Since they already had frogs in the game they decided just to go with the frogs and scrap the chickens idea. I have many question marks with that last statement???

Anyway the game is seriously worthy of a glance especially if it goes on sale...

reviewText: Autobiographical game and a surreal parabole about a relationship between a child and abusive parent with drinking problem. That alone makes Papo & Yo stand out. However actual gameplay consists of series of puzzles that are inventive and satisfying but never bring greater challenge as it is almost always obvious what to do. Jumping is imprecise at best and sadly there are few sections where you have to perform a double-jump in a very specific way which is not fun at all. I reccomend Papo & Yo for tackling with difficult topics and for creating a memorable experience.

reviewText:
Every now and then I find a game that is entirely mediocre in every way, and I have a hard time with my overall recommendation of it. Papo & Yo fits squarely into this category ‚Äì it‚Äôs never bad, but it‚Äôs never more than simply okay either.

For positives, I can easily say that Papo & Yo is a very pleasing game, visually. You spend the majority of your game time in a favela in Brazil, solving Alice in Wonderland-esque puzzles with floating platforms and clever mechanics which change your landscape in interesting ways. It doesn‚Äôt take very long to progress through, and feels mostly tight with controls and camera movements.

However, there seems to be just a layer of polish in all aspects that prevents this game from being better than average. The animations are choppy, and some game mechanics, such as jumping puzzles, may not feel as accurate as other platforming games.

The story is my main dividing point. Although the narrative is essentially a very dark memoir, everything that you really need to know about the tale is shown to you up front. When the curtains are pulled back for a big reveal, you are basically shown what you‚Äôve known since booting up the game ‚Äì the monster is your father, and the poisonous frogs that put him into an uncontrollable rage are bottles of alcohol. It almost seemed odd that they decided to spend so much time at the end of the game devoted to showing you this, as that is the outset of the game.

To be fair, Papo & Yo has its heart in the right place, it just could have used a little more time to shine up what‚Äôs already there. However, this game is entirely skippable. Not recommended, unless you can find it as part of a package deal or it‚Äôs on a steep sale.

reviewText: I purchased  this game a few weeks  ago just  because I saw the trailer and the gameplay reminded a lot of Ico for the Ps2, which is one of my fav games of all times. The gameplay of Papo & yo works in a similar way that Ico game, you get into areas, solved a couple of puzzles, turno on switches here and there and that's it. The game is simple, easy to go through and solved the puzzles. Now grafically speaking, the game is just BEAUTIFUL, the environment where the action takes place is just AWESOME, living in South America, in a awesome city with lots of hills and house build on them one above the other kinda feel like the action is taking place in mi city even thoug it's a mix of several architecture cities in South america (Chile, Brazil, Ecuador, Bolivia) which makes it more awesome because it's the first time I saw this kind of environment in a game. I should also  mention  the awesome art/painting in the walls of some buildings, they're incredible, I realized that those painting were actually done by  chilean artists and that some with similar designs are painted  in huge walls around my city, I just love it!!! As for the game quality, it's all thumbs up, music, art/design of the game no complains here and the story is deep, you can notice that the director put a lot of efforts in telling his own personal story and putting it into the game, lot of emotions, I think you should be a grown up to catch the whole plot to understand it though. The music is also excellent, so much that I decided to get the  OST as well.  To sum it up, this game is an excellent story telling/puzzle  kind of game well worth your money. I t won't be a waste I can assure you that.

reviewText:
Wow, what to say about this game!  When I bought this game, I did not know what to expect.  To be very honest, I did not even know what the game was about, other than it was an action/platformer game.  The story of this game is rather deep for such a childrens style game.

I don't really want to post any spoilers, but you run around as a kid named Quico whose father is an alcoholic.  You are in what seems to be a dream world where you have to solve puzzles and platform your way across each area to progress the story.  The puzzles are not overly hard, but the game is just fun and the story is a big metaphor.

The game is relatively short, but I believe you can play through twice just for the achievements.  Overall, this was one of the most enjoyable games I have played in the last year.  I did not want to stop playing! Part of me wishes it were longer, but another part is glad it was the length it was, because it did feel just right.

Anyhow, if you are looking for a action/platform/puzzle game that has a pretty good metaphoric driven story and is fun to boot, well I think this is right up your alley!
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText: I was gripped the moment the game loaded. From the artistic main menu, to the absolutely gorgeous look to the game, to the fluid game play and stellar control feel, this game is top notch. In fact it makes some of the other titles that I've been playing lately  all of a sudden feel mundane.\n\nI've noticed a few reviewers have felt the game to be boring, but this wasn't the case for me at all. It was SUCH a refreshing change from the usual gun and ammo seeking" games that have flooded the market. Trying to kill everything that moves before it kills you is not part of this game at all...you're actually trying to help someone who needs help. I suspect that those who didn't like this game fall into the COD or war gamer category
date:
and that's not me.

If you're remotely curious about this game then dive in and get it! You won't be disappointed.

9/10"

reviewText: Papo & Yo is a delightful platformer/puzzle game with a very interesting theme. Though the game might at first look seem like a fantasy story of a boy and a monster he befriends, it really is about growing up and coming to terms with your childhood. It is a game about how our imagination can help us cope with difficult times, until we are strong enough to take the masks off, see things for what they really are and accept reality for what it is.\nThe game itself isn't very challenging, but the platformer controls can be a bit finnicky from time to time. The environments of the game are well made and it is fun to see how the world shifts as you solve the puzzles. The game is fairly short but it definitely keeps you invested in it until its very appropriate and memorable ending.\nIn essense, Papo & Yo is not an extraordinary game, but it is a very good one. It has a strong and very personal message, one which I believe most people should be able to relate to one way or another. You can't go wrong with it.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Well whoops, here I thought this was a cute puzzle game.. Oh metaphors you sneaky sneaks you win again. That being said FANTASTIC story, good graphics,fitting soundtrack. The puzzles were just challenging enough to keep me interested. Really can not say much because I do not want to ruin the story for anyone whom might be interested in playing. All I will say is this is one of the better games I have played for a while and that maybe children of a certain age should NOT play it as I found out it is of more mature subject matter then previously expected, And that is why I always play my games first before letting my children play them (and that way it is more easy to help them acomplish puzzles and what-not). 9/10 two thumbs way up.

reviewText: Papo y Yo is a 3rd person action platformer. Its basic controls and easy to understand mechanics allows its charm to shine through. The story is centered around Quico, a south american boy, that sets out to find why he is cursed. He follows a mysterious girl around in search of the answer to his quest. He comes to find that his curse is to be paired with a monster who is usually disinterested in him but will turn in a moments notice and attack Quico when presented with some mysterious tree frogs. Quico has the ability, or the task, rather of manipulating his world. The south american favela setting is both oppressive and beautiful; at times the world is vivid and imaginative. Traversing the various puzzles can drastically change them in ways you would never expect.\nAs the story unfolds you come to find that the metaphors run deep and will certainly hit hard. The only complaint I have with Papo y Yo is that while the story is superb, it ends too soon. I suppose for the underlying subject matters, no spoilers, its best for this to be a short experience.\nThe game is beautiful, and easy to pick up and play. It's a 4 to 6 hour romp that is worth its asking price. Go check it out.

reviewText:
Papo & Yo is a lot of things. It's a 3D puzzle game. It's interactive magical realism. It's a meditation on abuse and alcoholism. It's pieced together with a real familiarity with and affection for the assembled look of Brazilian favelas. And it has a autobiographical tone that's nearly impossible to find elsewhere in games.

The gameplay is decent. The setting and music are strong. But the real star of the show is Monster. The game couldn't exist without him. For a creature that says nothing and spends half the game sleeping, he's fascinatingly complex. You'll switch between trying to protect him and trying to escape from him at a moment's notice. You're trying to break his addiction, but sometimes you'll use that addiction to force him to do what you want. You'll find yourself clinging to the brief moments he shows some affection, even if it's nothing more than a half-‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• toss of football. You want to like Monster, though you'll repeatedly ask yourself if you should even bother. It's a juggling act, but you'll find yourself practicing quite a bit of cognitive dissonance as you go from puzzle to puzzle.

The game isn't subtle in its metaphors, nor should it be. Think of it as a children's story about abuse. It's like Where the Wild Things Are, except instead of wild creatures as stand-ins for the anarchy of childhood, Monster stands for a child's perspective of the physical power, aloofness, and cruelty of adulthood.

Only about three hours of playing time. Mostly basic trouble solving. Most time in them is spent jumping around. One mechanic was not entirely obvious to me. You don't need a target on a wall to destroy the frogs. Just throw them at a wall.

It really probably won't be worth your time unless it's really cheap on sale or free.

reviewText:
Nice premise, but the slow pace killed it for me.

Gameplay
All you have to do during the game is jump, push and grab. Not complicated and nicely done. Aiming a jump was at times a bit difficult during the first playthrough. But during the second I was doing well, so I guess it was just a matter of practice.


Puzzles
Mainly easy but every now and then there was one I had to spend more time on. It may get tedious trying to resolve a puzzle when you are in A and go to B to pick something, return to A only to discover that whatever you picked was useless, go to C, return to A and then go to B to continue to the next puzzle.

The puzzles also mark very clearly the different stages in the game, 1 stage // 1 puzzle. For me this was one of the things that impaired the pace of the game.


Cinematics
During the game the cinematics are generally very well executed, meaning you can still control your character while watching them. I feel this is a very pleasant thing to be able to do.

However, there are times where a short cinematic would have been welcomed instead of a long sequence of doing nothing but waiting (when going to see the shaman, in the floating isle ). It was pretty frustrating being able to do nothing but turn in circles and playing with the camera.

There were times also, where I had the impression that the use of cinematics was unnecessary. There's a puzzle composed of 3 parts near the end of the game (when reviving Lula ) and after each part there is a cinematic telling you that yes! I had beaten that part yay. I know I have done it, I've just did it. Tell me I did well the first time if you want, but not all of them please.


Characters
Quico
Main character, nothing much to say about him.

Lula
Quico's favorite toy. Her (I'm going to assume she's female) first appearance presents her as a guide, she tells Quico how she can help him and how to make use of the new discovered abilities. But that is the only piece of dialogue she gets during the whole game and she becomes more of a tool than a friend.

Alejandra
Girl that teases Quico into following her and helps him to deal with Monster.

Monster
Big lumbering creature that burdens you throughout the game. You must make use of him in order to resolve most of the puzzles.

The death of Lula and Alejandra seemed forced, the character were killed because they acted stupidly, Lula could have dodged Monster and Alejandra shouldn't have stood jumping with and enraged Monster behind her. Although I feel those deaths were important, I believe they could have been implemented differently in order to appear more credible.


Achievements
Hats, why?


Although I gather the game has a lot of value I had not a great time playing it, and I'm sorry but a cannot recommend it.

reviewText: Brilliant puzzle game with excellent graphics, movement, and creativity.  Play as a little boy guided by a girl that has unique supernatural abilities but is convinced you are cursed.  Monster is a metephorical representation of the boys father, who has a penchant for poison frogs, and is quite dangerous after eating them.  He is needed in all his glory for the boy to get through the intricate puzzles however, and even when asleep can be quite useful.  I recommend this game to anyone that loves puzzle adventure games.

reviewText:
Papo & Yo is a story about a troubled childhood and using infinite imagination to escape, rationalize, endure... and, in the end,  let go of the troubled memories.

The story is presented in a spectacular and beautiful world, with impressive visuals and weird adventure-like puzzle design.

The entire game world is a metaphor, every element having real meaning- some things quite obviously so, while others are left for interpretation and discussion.

The game is neither long nor hard, but keeps throwing one impressive scene after another to constantly occupy the player's attention.

While it might not be everyone's cup of tea, I was definitely impressed and had to keep playing until I finished the story in one sitting. Take that as a recommendation if you wish :)

reviewText:
Random train of my thoughts on this game.

I'm all for interracial marriage, but Quico and his dad seemed to be completely different races.
Is Quico's continuous shedding of clothes on his journey supposed to be a metaphor of losing your childlike innocence when dealing with abusive parents?

And I wholly approve of this game's message to murder your alcoholic father by shoving him off a cliff.

Overall, a pretty game with a surprisingly heavy story, but I wouldn't pay the listed store price due to how quickly you can complete it. Definitely worth it to pick up from the Humble Bundle X though.

reviewText:
A Paladin's Steam Review: Papo and Yo. Lacking in Interesting Characters or Puzzles.Genre: 3rd Person Puzzle Platformer Title
Developed & Published by: Minority Media Inc.
Platform: Windows Only
Business Model: Base Game.
Copy Purchased by Myself Overall Gameplay Thoughts & Preamble
I was rather interested in giving this a whirl when it came out a few years ago. Fast-forward to this past week and I finally got a chance to try it out. Well, this game makes two major mistakes to me. First: the characters are given very little backstory or personality. You could swap in any person to fill the role of these characters and it would come off as the same. The other problem is the puzzles themselves. They mostly range from really easy to unnecessarily frustrating. Not even the good kind of frustrating, just time-wasting frustration. So, let‚Äôs dig in and talk about Papo & Yo.

Story Thoughts
I've seen comments been made that the game‚Äôs story is subtle and full of meaning. I found that it was rather blunt and in your face with its themes about living with people that abuse alcohol. I mean, a shadow in the shape of Monster behind a guy, it‚Äôs just not that subtle. The toy getting destroyed by Monster wasn't all that subtle. I do recall that I wanted to know more about the main character, more about this mysterious girl who‚Äôs guiding you around. Instead, you‚Äôre given very little information. The story seems content to focus on one little part of the boy‚Äôs past. It's hard to get invested when you're not given any character to invest into. So, if I can‚Äôt get invested in the characters or story, all that‚Äôs left is the gameplay. And for the most part, it‚Äôs boring.

Puzzles
A lot of the puzzles consist of getting monster from one place to the other using what few items and environment puzzle pieces you have at your disposal. Most of the time though, it‚Äôs climbing up ladders, doing very basic platforming, puzzling with levers, switches and buttons. Each puzzle is overly long and unsatisfying to finish. I can‚Äôt help but get the impression they were put in to stretch the game out. Especially when one particular puzzle has you climbing all over rooftops and platforms to collect around 10 pieces of building in order to finish it. There isn't a lot of nuance, its figuring out the quirk of the puzzle you've stumbled upon and then sinking however many hours the puzzle decides you need to until you finish it.

PC Settings
It‚Äôs got texture, shadow, AA, light shafts, motion blur, bloom, depth of field and all other graphic settings a 3rd person game requires to tweak. Most, however, are on/off switches but at least you have options to optimize your experience. Not that I think you‚Äôll need to tweak with them much, the game isn't very demanding. You may need to tune up the gamma settings as the game seemed really dark to me.

Final Thoughts
Finishing the game isn‚Äôt tough. However, this is one particular journey that I didn‚Äôt feel better for having experienced. I think the main problem lies in the characters themselves. I felt no investment into them, no reason to find moments evocative when perhaps I should have. It feels like this subject has been handled better elsewhere. Add that problem to the other problem of the simple, time-wasting puzzles that were far more frustrating than they should have been. I don't recommend this title. This has been done better.

Read this review and more on A Paladin Without A Crusade[kingisaaclinksr.com]

reviewText:
Papo & Yo is a puzzle game, however that is also where it fails the hardest. The puzzles in the game seem to be designed in such a way to waste as much of your time as possible, not because they're difficult (which none of them actually are), but because of the massive amount of running around that is required for solving each and every single one of them.

The second major fault of the game is the clunky way of trying to control the monster to do what you want him to do, the mechanic is contrived, again simply to add to the play time.

The storyline is very thin, the game tries to allude to things, however everything is already blatantly clear long before the conclusion of the game. And the soundtrack is almost equally nonexistant, most of the time there is no background music playing at all and the rest of time it's only sometimes interesting.

All in all Papo & Yo Desperately tries to be much more clever than it actually is.

However despite all its faults the game had me mildly entertained throughout, the atmosphere it tried to create was enough for me to finish the game, and because of the short play time and more importantly without any major setbacks there was nothing stopping me from doing so.

5 / 10

reviewText:
Drowsy game.  Boring. Puzzles are simple, one-directional, and tedious to complete, with the premise of going from point A, to point B, then A once again, to finish it in C.

In the hour and a half that I've been playing, I've enjoyed 2 dynamical and original puzzles, while I suffered of boredom the remaining hour and 20 mins.

Wouldn't recommend it because:

1. Gameplay is too repetitive, soft, and boring.
2. The first phrase when you start the story reveals everything.

Yes, the story is touching, but the time you have to suffer playing betwen cutscenes is NOT worth it, in my opinion.

reviewText:
This game doesn't have much replay value, unless you want to get 100% on the achievements.
I could predict what was going to happen, and who the characters would end up representing in Quico's life. If there was a plot twist, or the elements in the conclusion were more hidden and not as obvious I would have taken more gratitude to it. But for the repetitive and tedious puzzle sequences it dulled the gameplay because I already knew what would do what and how it would be done.
Don't get me wrong, the storyline IS there, but the fillers for what little storyline is present consists of moving gears and wishing your walkspeed was faster.
The visuals are great, as well as the decorations, I was constantly exploring the maps out of curiosity and hoping that I would run into an easteregg (I found one near the end of the game).
For full price, I do not recommend buying this game because it is quite short, and your money would be better invested in a game where you could spend many hours on. Plus, the storyline is present, but not very strong. If you are considering buying it during a sale (I got mine 75% off), then I say there is no harm  if you have done your research and know this is a game you will enjoy for its price.

reviewText:
Papa and Yo is not Subtle. It takes its abusive father metaphor and beats you over the head with it. I applaud what the creator is trying to do; even more so knowing its based on his childhood but, I think the game needs a better writer.

Plot:
The plot is about you letting go of your abusive and alcoholic father. Its not a bad place to start but thats all the game has plot wise. Very little character building or reasons to get attached to the characters. The only other npc is a girl that helps/hinders you who may be your sister but is unliklely due to the lighter skin color and almost no resemblance to you. *spoiler* She dies... or just gets abused.

I have to say, I hate ambiguity. Not that ambiguity itself is bad, but few people know how, and when, to use it. Papa and Yo uses it as a crutch because 'I guess' the writers could fill the gaps with something they thought was interesting? I dont think the ambiguity is needed as much as they used it.

Gameplay
The gameplay consists of puzzle platformers. They are very simple puzzles and it gives you hints if you get stuck. Pretty bog standard as far as these things go

Aesthetic
This is where I feel the game wins. Its damn beautiful with creative use of the environment to assist the puzzles. With the exception of a few technical pop ins, the game looked great.

Sound
The sound was... alright. It did the jobs but nothing really stood out. There were also moments, like at the temple when you make the monster angry, a short music piece plays over the normal music and it doesnt sound good.

Length
Its 2 hours. Im not sure if thats good or bad considering I wasn't really having fun, or an interesting experience. I feel like any more and I would have just stopped playing. At least I beat it because of its short length?


If you really like puzzle platformer and non subtle plot threads strewn with ambiguity, then this game is for you. If not; give it a pass.

reviewText:
EDIT: I'm happy to see my review isn't the only one with an absurd amount of dislikes since I simply put this over-hyped game into actual perspective. It looks as though the major fans of this game are a little immature, downrating a negative review since it simply doesn't agree with their opinion.

Quite honestly one of the most dull and lifeless indie games in a long time. The developer seems to think that the player needs each reference explained to them. The puzzles are way too easy, which isn't always a bad thing so long as there is a deeply enjoyable story to accompany them. In the case of Papo & Yo the tale is less than thrilling, and not just because it's about a topic that will appeal to very few people; it's because the story is executed poorly.

By the end of it all the gamer will feel no emotional ties to the Monster or Quico, Lula the robot toy is the only one with a personality that isn't as dull as a rock. This title is one to avoid, but if you insist then for the price of $14.99 USD you're better off waiting until this one appears in a Humble or Indie Gala Bundle, or is on a heavy discount. The game play only lasts for a maximum of 5 hours; I completed my playthrough in a little under three and a half hours.

Papo & Yo is short, but powerful; powerful enough that I couldn't write a review immediately after playing it, because it was all still a little too intense.

I picked this game up as part of a Humble Bundle, knowing absolutely nothing about it, and installed it when I was in the mood for a bit of indie whimsy.  So it came as a bit of a shock when the opening animation sequence  made it clear that child abuse was going to be a prominent theme of the game -- I had been expecting cheery, light-hearted fluff, and this was looking instead like a terrible downer.  Within a few minutes, however, the setting and gameplay had drawn me in so much that I played all the way through in one sitting, even though I knew the game was writing me a ticket on the feels train.

The setting is an appealingly surrealist dreamscape rendition of a South American favela, blending fanciful magic with rusty corrugated iron sheets.  The frequent puzzles are inventive and fun, if not particularly challenging.  But the puzzles aren't the true star of this game; story is the shining star here.   Monster, your companion through most of the game, is a very thinly veiled portrayal of an abusive alcoholic father, and what the game does brilliantly is lead you into the mindset of a victim.  You'll love Monster, fear him, hate him, resent him and even pity him, often at the same time.  You'll find yourself doing ugly, violent things without even thinking about it, because you desperately need to avoid triggering Monster's rage.  You'll make excuses for Monster; you'll blame other things; you'll blame yourself.  You'll allow yourself to believe that you're in control -- that if you just play the game well enough, you can keep Monster content and placid indefinitely.  And, inevitably, it will all come crashing down on you.

reviewText: A solid, short little puzzle adventure game with a unique setting and beautifully crafted everything. I would have enjoyed it more if the metaphor wasn't so blatantly obvious and written right on the box, but it is defintely worth playing regardless.
I honestly do not even know why I bought this game in the first place.\n

Score: 8/10
Similar Games
Alice Madness Returns

Overview
You play as a young boy who winds up in a magical world where chalk lines create magic. You see another kid who you immediately start trying to follow. Soon you meet up with monster. He is a friendly, hungry, and sleepy bugger. When monster eats frogs he goes into a fiery rage trying to chase down and hit you. If he does eat a frog you must give him a blue edible and he turns back to normal again. You must traverse the strange world by jumping around and solving chalk line puzzles.

The Good
The hidden story in this game about his father's alcoholism is done in a very suddle way. Don't worry about that spoiler it doesn't wreck the experience, but actually enhances it know whats going on. The platforming is done well and the world has great music and visual style coming off very innocent. The puzzles are well done and feel fresh throughout.

The Bad
Though the story is touching and the world is done well the game is very short. I also feel like the story could have been more involved throughout instead of mostly at the very end. You don't really gain much in terms of new abilities other then the double jump. The world looks nice, but the resources used in it don't change up hardly at all.

Conclusion
Papo & Yo has a bit of a limited world and limited amount of characters, but what it does do is real you in with cute charm while secretly telling you a story about a childs struggle with his alcoholic father. The emotion and visual style are very impactful, but the short length and scope of the game do hinder what it could have been slightly.

Value
The game is more like a short emotional art game with no real replay value so I'd say $5
Long enough to call itself an adventure, short enough to get it's consice message across.

Exquisitely beautiful and deeply nuanced, Papo & Yo asks of its audience that they enter into a relationship with a monster, one that they're almost sure to regret.

I heard of Papo & Yo by chance, from a friend. It's a small game -- with only about 3-4 hours of gameplay -- from the even smaller Minority development team, based in Montreal. With an August 2012 release date, it's also relatively old by game standard; I bought it back in June on a whim, torn between rave reviews by people I knew and a few spectacularly bad ones by games journalists (although, if IGN still counts as games journalism by the time anyone's reading this, I will be well and truly shocked). I didn't touch it at all until very recently.

But Papo & Yo lives up to cult hype. Although relatively simple -- possibly too simple for anyone who doesn't struggle with puzzles and platformers the way I do -- the game's breathtaking environments, incredible soundtrack, charming cast and biting narrative are more than enough to compensate even the most hardcore" of gamers. reviewText: A great emotional game that is based on the game designers own childhood.

This game is, in a word, stunning.

Since I opened Papo & Yo, I've been admittedly obsessed. The way that the developers (Minority) managed to tie in mature and serious themes like alcoholism and domestic violence without using gratuitous violence or gore is commendable. In fact, Papo & Yo doesn't contain any gore at all! The story is truly captivating and you find yourself getting increasingly attached to the characters as time goes on, despite the minimal use of dialogue.

The gameplay itself is mainly a mix of casual puzzles and platforming. It's a simplistic way of bolstering the narrative, and was implemented amazingly. There are only a few achievements, but I had a lot of fun getting them all. A second playthrough of the game allows for collecting hats (which appear on dolls seen throughout the game).

I'm not one for writing serious reviews, but this game is deserving of nothing short of a proper review. Completing this game felt like a spiritual experience, and I'll be sure to do it again soon. Whatever the price is for this game right now, it's worth every penny.

Papo & Yo is fantastic! amazing visuals, a moving story that everyone should experience (see also: Gone Home), fun puzzles, and you can see it all in just 3 hours! super-plus-good!\n\n(divide my play time by 3. that's how many friends I've had over and sat down to play Papo & Yo. none have regretted it.)

Papo & Yo tells an interesting and sad story about a little boy, his father and life itself. It gives you some challenging puzzles and some collectibles, but the main focus is on unraveling the story behind the strange world you will find yourself in.\n\nGood graphics, good gameplay, great soundtrack - I'd say this is a steady 8/10 on my list.

You could describe this game as a 3d person puzzle platformer. But it has a strong art style and emotional theme which makes it really unique. The story elements and characters in the game are very memorable, and the game is very good at invoking an emotional response as it has a deep theme.

The art style is very clever. It looks like a city in a developing country, so it is an interesting game world to explore. But all the puzzles are environmental, you can move houses, collapse walls and generally change the world around you to progress. There is also a lot of platforming to move around and help solve the puzzles but it is not punishing.

The world gets more and more abstract as you progress and as you piece together the background story. After playing a number of AAA games back to back, this game was a breath of fresh air and I really enjoyed it.
Really uses the media of gaming to transport the player into the mindscape of the character. Very beautiful and very raw.  Must experience first hand.

This is one of the most amazing games I've ever played. If you're interested in very good story and symbolism and drug addiction, this game is for you. I love it so much. It's emotive and beautiful at every turn.

Rating : 8/10

With good gameplay (although the puzzles seem slightly repetitive), graphics, and atmosphere, this game isn't exactly notable or special, but it's not bad.

However, I loved the story. Monster is actually an analogy for the developer's drunk, abusive father as the frogs that enrage him are symbolic of alcohol and the whole game appears to be the boy's own Wonderland. It only progressed in little bits and pieces, but those were enough to make it something I will remember. Although it did go very slow, you were able to ignore the story every now and then to just focus on the puzzle.

It's also a game that's fun and easy to 100%, assuming you have the time for it. There are 25 hidden hats and 10 achievements that are easy to get but worth trying for.

I was sceptical of the game at first and only had it in my library as part of a humble bundle. Upon starting to play it as it was in my library anyway, I noticed that it had a great Soundtrack as well as nice animation. Even though the game seems like it is directed at children sometimes, it is still moving and at points very complex. Parts of the game actually did make me cry. I can only recommend this game to anyone.\n
The puzzles are delightful (you throw buildings around!) and the story is so well done. Short, but worthwhile.

Overall a good game, I recommend it, although if you're looking for complex puzzle, that won't happen here... (maybe after the second hour of play...) But usually, puzzle are quite easy since you just need to look for the white-shiny-thing and once you've found it, that's it, you're good to go... Oh and also, sometimes you have to go over a long distance to do a thing who seems to be there just to make sure you won't finish the game in 2 hours, but in 3.... (some sad back and forth between things in the puzzle)

Beside that, the story, the music, the visual and the emotion the game creates is awesome... The visual are gorgeous and the way everything moves in this world is real genius...

I had quite some fun playing it!
nice indie&puzzle game. finished this game twice. it was really fun to play and has heart touching story line.
A most intriguing game.  Simple yet very clever and amospheric puzzle game that draws you in.  Highly recommended and a big thumbs up to the Developers.  A must buy. :)

I don't like platformer.  I don't like jumping puzzles.  I especially don't like timing puzzles.  I'm not very good at any of those.  Because of that, I should not have liked this game.  But I did.  I liked this game a lot.

The gameplay was simple enough that I could play through it without getting seriously frustrated by my lack of skill; but still challenging enough not to be boring.   The puzzles that did not involve jumping and timing were very clever, but for the most part still logical and intuitive once you got into the flow of the game.  There were a few odd moments where the puzzles did not make a whole lot of sense, and I was force to rely on a walkthrough; but very few (unlike so many modern puzzle games, where randomness is used as a cheap and easy substitute for cleverness).  The mechanics of the game are very entertaining in themselves, particularly once Lulu is introduced.

The game design is beautiful; and the creators use of an uncommon setting was brilliant.  The third-world backdrop meshed very well with the fantastical elements; creating a seamless world with it's own unique and readily-identifiable logic.  The artwork is stunning, and the inclusion of works by actual environmental artists nothing short of amazing.  The similar use of third-world characters, rather than white Europeans or stereotypical fantasy creatures is similarly inspiring.  The music is beautiful, and in spots almost breathtaking, wonderfully blending traditional and orchestral sounds.  Atmospheric and fun at the same time.

I would be hard pressed to find any flaws in the game.  If I did, I would say that parts of the ending felt a little out of place.  Some of the scenes and actions didn't make quite as much sense as they could have, and the symbolism is a bit heavyhanded; but that's still a fairly minor quibble.   The game is a bit shorter than most of its type; but too much longer and it would have started to drag.  The pacing never leave it feeling too long or too short.

One warning is that the background story that emerges from the game is disturbing, becoming increasingly so the closer it gets to the end.  This is ultimately a story of addiction and child abuse; and is accordingly dark and sad.  Fortunately, the writers do not beat the player over the head with moralizing; and manage to balance the darkness with a keen sense of human resilience.

I cannot recommend this game enough.  I picked it up at a huge discount during one of Steam's big sales; but would can easily recommend getting it even at full price.
This game has an amazing story. Don't be fooled by the beautiful visuals and fun mechanics it is not all smiles in Quico's world. The story is touching and the game is fun to play. Get it!

reviewText: If you liked Shadow of the Collossus for the giant building-like creatures or the general look of Brazil's favelas , you'll probably like some of the imagery in this.  Ultimately though, the puzzles more or less were busy work, the monster lacked any sort of intimidation once he catches you once, the story was frustrating and the conclusion bludgeoned you with its meaning, leaving no ambiguity.\n\nStill, it's not a long game, it's charming enough that it doesn't deserve to be completely panned and ignored. Pick it up for cheap if you can.

Just wow. Concise and poignant, this game is filled with sublime vistas of childhood wonder brought to life. The gameplay itself is elegant, and the mechanics reinforce the narrative of the game. I cannot say enough to convey how amazingly well executed the theme and story of the game is, from the devolving normalcy of the scenarios you encounter, to the sparse but powerful cutscenes that hit you like trainwreck.

By the time I was done, I had become a bundle of emotions, both profoundly sad yet simultaneously uplifted by the ordeal I had participated in. The game reads as a catharsis on the part of it lead designer, Vander Callabero, and I wonder if its narrative could be, in part, healing for those who have gone through similar crises. I'd challenge anyone who doesn't believe that video games can be art to play this game and still support that opinion.

Stop reading this and just go and experience this story.

This is one of those games that shows the problems that some children suffer daily, it can be played by anyone to explain that not everyone is as fortunate as others and the true nature of how our imagination works to get away from our problems to be in  a better place. I would recommend this to anyone that has a few hours to play this fantastic and inspiring game.

This is a rare gem in the gaming world that you shouldn't pass up.

I don't like platformer.  I don't like jumping puzzles.  I especially don't like timing puzzles.  I'm not very good at any of those.  Because of that, I should not have liked this game.  But I did.  I liked this game a lot.

The gameplay was simple enough that I could play through it without getting seriously frustrated by my lack of skill; but still challenging enough not to be boring.   The puzzles that did not involve jumping and timing were very clever, but for the most part still logical and intuitive once you got into the flow of the game.  There were a few odd moments where the puzzles did not make a whole lot of sense, and I was force to rely on a walkthrough; but very few (unlike so many modern puzzle games, where randomness is used as a cheap and easy substitute for cleverness).  The mechanics of the game are very entertaining in themselves, particularly once Lulu is introduced.

The game design is beautiful; and the creators use of an uncommon setting was brilliant.  The third-world backdrop meshed very well with the fantastical elements; creating a seamless world with it's own unique and readily-identifiable logic.  The artwork is stunning, and the inclusion of works by actual environmental artists nothing short of amazing.  The similar use of third-world characters, rather than white Europeans or stereotypical fantasy creatures is similarly inspiring.  The music is beautiful, and in spots almost breathtaking, wonderfully blending traditional and orchestral sounds.  Atmospheric and fun at the same time.

I would be hard pressed to find any flaws in the game.  If I did, I would say that parts of the ending felt a little out of place.  Some of the scenes and actions didn't make quite as much sense as they could have, and the symbolism is a bit heavyhanded; but that's still a fairly minor quibble.   The game is a bit shorter than most of its type; but too much longer and it would have started to drag.  The pacing never leave it feeling too long or too short.

One warning is that the background story that emerges from the game is disturbing, becoming increasingly so the closer it gets to the end.  This is ultimately a story of addiction and child abuse; and is accordingly dark and sad.  Fortunately, the writers do not beat the player over the head with moralizing; and manage to balance the darkness with a keen sense of human resilience.

I cannot recommend this game enough.  I picked it up at a huge discount during one of Steam's big sales; but would can easily recommend getting it even at full price.

Since I opened Papo & Yo, I've been admittedly obsessed. The way that the developers (Minority) managed to tie in mature and serious themes like alcoholism and domestic violence without using gratuitous violence or gore is commendable. In fact, Papo & Yo doesn't contain any gore at all! The story is truly captivating and you find yourself getting increasingly attached to the characters as time goes on, despite the minimal use of dialogue.

The gameplay itself is mainly a mix of casual puzzles and platforming. It's a simplistic way of bolstering the narrative, and was implemented amazingly. There are only a few achievements, but I had a lot of fun getting them all. A second playthrough of the game allows for collecting hats (which appear on dolls seen throughout the game).

I'm not one for writing serious reviews, but this game is deserving of nothing short of a proper review. Completing this game felt like a spiritual experience, and I'll be sure to do it again soon. Whatever the price is for this game right now, it's worth every penny.

Papo & Yo has what many of the current generation games lack: a good history

reviewText: The best game i've played all year. Not a lot to say, it was beautifully done. The music was elegant (going to buy the OST), the gameplay was fluid and enjoyable and the storyline (hit's ya right in the feels) was a breath of fresh air. I wish I had played this earlier, but am glad that I had a chance to experience it.

This is an all around stunning game. From the level design, texture quality, and unique animations to sound design to the beautifully crafted narrative of which the game is focused, nothing fails to impress. The gameplay is based around puzzles/platforming in a three-dimensional environment. The gameplay does not present much of a challenge but the controls are solid and intuitive, playing great with gamepad or keyboard/mouse. The music and ambient environmental sounds are immersive and calming, allowing for a stark contrast when the narrative calls for it. The narrative deals with themes of addiction, abuse, and denial through excellent use of imagery and symbolism.\nEverything fits together amazingly well in this game. It's rare to find a game that so excellently parses mature themes without resorting to mindless violence. I've been playing games for fifteen years, and I can honestly say this is one of the best. I bought it on sale not knowing what to expect and having beaten it, I gladly would have paid many times over the price for such an experience.

Papo & Yo is a surreal puzzle platformer set in an urban landscape, seen through the whimsical imagination of a child. Beneath the surface however is a darker theme. Think Life of Pi meets Inception.\n\nWhile the game is a bit lacking in terms of graphics and animation the story and it's delivery along with the unique and fun mechanics of the game more than make up for it.

reviewText: My god. This game dredged up memories of a time when I had to let go of a best friend of mine because of illegal drug use. It was alcohol specifically, that made me decide. In the moment when he broke into a liquor cabinet and began to get drunk, (while of course being underage.), I was afraid. I let him get drunker and drunker, and when he was stumbling around and falling down, I got in my car, (which had his stuff and the stuff of the people who were with us.) , and I left and drove to his parents house. I deposited everyone's stuff on the front porch and rang the doorbell and told his dad where he was and what he was doing. Afterwords, I never looked back. I haven't seen him in years now, nor do I want to, but I just know, if I saw him again I could become friends again with him easily. But I took the harder route of not forgiving him and simply letting him go. The ending of Papo and Yo was a metaphor for an actual moment in my life, and it was one of , if not THE most, moving ending to a video game I have ever seen. Millage may vary for other people, but at least for me, I felt very moved. It was just like revisiting that moment again, but this time, I was able to let go more easily. This is a game that simply must be played. It is a beautiful piece of art.
This game is more than just platforming and puzzle solving. It brought tears to my eyes at just how emotional it was. You owe it to yourself and your feels to play this.
Donde esta el nariz? El nariz es en el bano.\n\nDonde esta el perrito de closete? El perrito de closete esta en el closete.
This game plays like a third person Portal meets Inception (you'll know what I mean if you play it). A gorgeous looking puzzler that I can strongly recommend.

The puzzle platforming is simple and engaging.  But that isn't the draw.  This is the kind of cathartic art that someone creates in therapy.  It's like a black and white painting of a beaten child in a dark corner under a spotlight.  It is blunt, it is abrupt and it is unsubtle, but it will evoke a powerful emmotional response.

Papo & Yo is about as close to a breakthrough where games transcend art/entertainment, and become a catharsis for personal emotions.  This truly feels like the the creator of the game wants you to relive some tragic events that shaped his life, and asks you to participate in a safe and engaging way.  At times, it takes the horrible and makes something beautiful out of it.  A must play.

This is a very touching and thoughtful game. Some of it's metaphors (primarily alcoholism and abuse) are clear, but I find myself still wondering if other aspects of the game could be metaphorical as well.  I recommend it, but I will say that the play time is pretty low.  I beat it in a little over three hours.  I would probably wait for a deep discount.
Pan's Labyrinth + SPATE - eeriness = Papo y Yo

Very inventive little indie puzzle(ish) game. The world its in is a sort of magical dream take on the favelas of brazil, almost Neil Gaiman-like, and that is a very *very* amazing thing to see. The premise is also very deeply inter-twined with the gameplay, and the world building. Can't reveal too much but the title is very much representative, for better and worse.\n\n(9/10, and add half a point if your from a troubled family)

Deceptively charming, Papo & Yo is an allegorical tale about a young boy trying to regain control of a life disrupted by his father's drinking and the monstrous rages that follow.

It's carefully slow in introducing mechanics, and highly visual in the presentation of both its puzzles and hints, the latter of which can be found in cardboard boxes located near their respective puzzles. Tutorials are presented similarly, but there are occasional places where the player is left to muddle through alone.

Saving is handled through liberally supplied checkpoints, and there are no dead ends or death scenes, though it is possible in some scenes to fall out of the playable area and 'fade to white' before reappearing in a safe location.

Absolutely brilliant game, I really enjoyed every moment of it.  Though a little short it's well worth the playthrough again and again.  The story was bittersweet, music was beautiful and the visuals were just stunning.

A 3D puzzle platformer set in a fantastical favela. Inspired by the personal story of one of the creators, Papo & Yo explores some dark themes.\n\nWhile the game quickly became find-the-chalk-drawing, all the contraptions were always fun to watch and filled with child-like imagination.

This is a very personal game about a boy trying to befriend his abusive parent. It has an unexpected and emotionally powerful ending, just like Brothers. Papo & Yo also excels in gameplay - lots of exploration, platforming and puzzles in a surreal ghetto, where the chalkboard drawings of children magically come to life. Also, it's an indie game that tries and almost succeeds at having a triple A quality and polish. One of the best games that came out this year.
A real piece of art.
A hidden gem, a masterpiece, it's glorious and extremely inventive.

Papo & Yo is an amazing puzzle platform game. The puzzles aren't that challenging but the imaginative ideas that went into this game make up for it. So much is said with such little dialog; simply a must buy.

Very Poignant and Beautiful.  A short but satisfying experience.

There's not too much I can say about this game without spoiling the plot and diminishing its emotional impact, but here's what I will say.

This game is relatively simple, as far as mechanics go. It's a basic puzzle/platformer; it isn't too difficult skill-wise, nor will you likely get stumped by any of the puzzle elements. Mechanically it's actually a very easy game - even taking my time and messing up a bit here and there, I still finished it in less than 4 hours. Despite that, it was one of the most difficult games for me to complete on an emotional level.

I really relate to the main character, Quico. What this game lacks in mechanical complexity it completely makes up for in emotional intensity and engagement. It will hit you right in the feels, over and over. It's not hard to tell that this was a very personal subject for the game's main creator, and I think he and the creative team tackled it very well. They have my utmost gratitude for making this game. Honestly, if anyone ever asks me about my relationship with my stepfather, rather than explain it to them with words I could just have them play this game. It definitely goes onto my favorites list, and although I can't say it's one I'll play again anytime soon, I'm very much grateful for the experience it brought me.
