There's not too much I can say about this game without spoiling the plot and diminishing its emotional impact, but here's what I will say.

This game is relatively simple, as far as mechanics go. It's a basic puzzle/platformer; it isn't too difficult skill-wise, nor will you likely get stumped by any of the puzzle elements. Mechanically it's actually a very easy game - even taking my time and messing up a bit here and there, I still finished it in less than 4 hours. Despite that, it was one of the most difficult games for me to complete on an emotional level.

I really relate to the main character, Quico. What this game lacks in mechanical complexity it completely makes up for in emotional intensity and engagement. It will hit you right in the feels, over and over. It's not hard to tell that this was a very personal subject for the game's main creator, and I think he and the creative team tackled it very well. They have my utmost gratitude for making this game. Honestly, if anyone ever asks me about my relationship with my stepfather, rather than explain it to them with words I could just have them play this game. It definitely goes onto my favorites list, and although I can't say it's one I'll play again anytime soon, I'm very much grateful for the experience it brought me.

A very beautiful game. I played this back to back with Portal 2 and at first I was a little disappointed with Papo & Yo's puzzles by comparison. As the game went on though I came to appreciate that Papo & Yo has different goals than Portal and as a result different puzzles. Papo & Yo, to me at least, is a metaphor for navigating family dynamics. Its goal is to put you in a child's shoes, to oscillate between the calm and terror of having an alcoholic father, not to offer arbitrary brain teasers.

If you like a game for its story, Papo and Yo may be right for you. The game employs intriguing and abstract puzzle mechanics that will make you smile. It is not a difficult game, but it wasn't meant to be. The relaxing atmosphere of the game leaves room for its players to take in the surroundings, understand an important message, and find a few little secrets.

This is a stunning piece of artwork, and a moving story. The gameplay itself is fun and whimsical, but it's the story that really pulled on my heartstrings. I'll never forget this experience. Highly reccomend this.

I managed to beat it in around 3-4 hours.

But it was a well-enjoyed 3-4 hours. Like a lot of indie games, it's meant to be experienced more than anything. But it's not really something that tries too hard to be overly deep and the symbolism is made pretty clear by the end. In fact, the second trailer pretty much spells it out for you before you play. The game draws inspiration from the creator's real life experiences with an alcoholic father. It's good, but you may want to take a pass if themes like alcholism and abuse are overwhelming to you.

I'd rather not give away the ending, so I'll just say that if you want to see it, you'll have to play for yourself. I personally think it would be worth the $15, although I got it on sale. But since not everyone might agree with me, I'd say just get it on the next sale if you're not 100% sure. You might not feel like you're getting much out of it as a game. It's short and pretty simple. But as an experience, I'd recommend it.

Papo & Yo is about a boy with an abusive father who escapes into a fantasy world where he needs the help of a brutish monster named Papo to help you slove platforming puzzles.

This game is very pretty.  bright, colorful, and atmospheric.  The tone and art style gradually changes as the story progresses and grows darker.

Most of the game involves using Papo to help you get around by lifting obsticals or tossing you to high ledges and then you need to manipulate the enviroment so Papo can follow.  There are also slugs that Papo really loves but cause him to go into a rage and attack anything near him including you.  Sometimes you need to keep him away from the slugs sometimes you need to let him eat them so you can solve a puzzle.  It's hear were your relationship with the monster begins to mirror your relationship with your abusive father.

The game does have some flaws.  its not the longest game, sometimes the physics are a little wonky and there could be a bit more variety in the game play but its not enough to be a deal breker

The mechanics are not very interesting, the puzzles are simplistic and repetitive, the pacing is weird, the difficulty curve is.....not a curve, the characters are not particularly well-developed.\n\nI still think you should play it.  The unique visuals and mechanics and tone completely make it worth 4 hours of your time.  And the theme may be a little clumsy and on-the-nose, but better for a game to try something cool and not quite make it than be bland and samey.

Papa & Yo is a tale of a boy and his Big peach-coloured-monster that in a less than subtle way is a metaphor for an alcoholic parental figure. The monster likes bright orange coconuts and can be manipulated to go and stand at places that makes bright white magic happen.

What's appealing about this experience is how this dream world is portrayed, and less so in how it functions.
The box city is vivid and playfully represented; cardboard boxes being picked up will make houses fly and move about to be placed in strategic places for our avatar to step on in order to progress.
Some houses will grow legs and move like cockroaches, others grow wings and fly.
I find these houses and what they mean to the main character more appealing than what the game tries to make me feel for the monster.

The monster is nothing but a tool for the main character to use in order to trigger bright white magic so that you can progress. I don't feel for the monster, and also with all this creative freedom that the kid has, why doesn't he make his way through without the monster? It means nothing to me as a player, there is no love.
The monster might just have been a ball and a chain locked to the kids foot.
And then when the frogs enter the picture, making the monster go inte a fiery rage when he consumes them, the monster's tediousness just increases making me like it less.
And liking it less would be fine if there just were some moment before that that established some kind of positive connection, but that never happens.

It would serve whatever narrative the game is trying to convey better if the monster was simply always there, following and being present without forcing me as a player to make it go places all the time.

But instead the game is tediously forcing the player to go through puzzles that after repetition loses what the game is trying to say about the relationship this kid has with the monster, the world, the girl, the robot and cardboard houses.

The movement felt when moving the character about is fluent and loose but comes to a chunky halt when the game demands you to yet again turn arbitrary levers in order to progress.
Or to make the monster do more stuff for you. Again.

I did enjoy what I played for the most part, with a little more thought put into what the puzzles could mean set to the context of what this boy is going through, it could've succeeded in saying something.

'Papa & Yo' has heart and genuinely cares, but needs more thought on how to make the theme of the game correlate with the player's choices.

I don't usually present 100% positive reviews, but when I do... this is what they look like.

Papo & Yo is, without a doubt, one of the best games I have played in a long time. It's beautiful, it's moving, it's elegantly made. Just difficult enough to be challenging, but not difficult enough to take away from the essential quality of the game -- which is the story itself.

I do feel that it deserves a trigger warning -- if you trigger on child abuse, this game needs to be approached with caution. But it is so very, very worth it.

This was one of the extremely few games I have ever played where I felt the story matched the gameplay. The puzzles, while rather easy, were still fun to execute, but that was forgotten as the graphics, music, and actual gameplay were absolutely beautiful. I adored this game.

I have mixed feelings about Papo & Yo.
On the other hand I want to love the game for it's unique feel, but on the other I feel it is lacking on many fronts.
At it's best Papo & Yo offers beautiful artwork and sceneries, entertainment and a fun challenge. At it's worst, it is very repetitive, frustrating and even boring. It also hosts a selection of glitches, that aren't that big of a deal, but do leave an unpolished impression.

The story had me intrigued at first, but lost me after a while because of it's slow progress. Also, it's really not well carried out tbh. I did however finish the game for I wanted to get to the predictable end. Seeing the credits scroll down on the screen didn't offer the satisfaction I thought it would, other than finally getting the game off my to-do list. It was a bit like finishing a mediocre book.

Still, I won't advice to steer clear of the game. If you have the patience and are willing to forgive some annoyances (many that are due to budget) Papo & Yo delivers a different kind of gameplay experience that other game makers should learn from and improve on. It is good to see that more and more people like Vander Caballero (the creative director, who the story is based on) take the effort to get off their high horses at big game studios to go and discover their own path.
Addictive game !! It  seems to be simple but sometimes you 'll be surprised .  It is a wonderful & original game for the 7 to 77 years olds.

Hands down I would recomend Papo & Yo to andbody, indie gamer or not. This game is a silent yet moving experience that I found had a perfect balance between the dark and light aspects of both atomosphere and gameplay. The contrast between the light atomosphere and darker narriative adds to the overarching experience and gives insight into how the main character experiences the story. I have not yet seen this on anyones games of the year list but this would for sure be in my top 5.

It will make you feel.  This interactive media makes you look at pain and love.  Specifically the pain caused by an evil drunken father and the confusing love felt by a son.  You feel along with the son.  The son loves his sister and she is also in pain.  The confusion of having a father,  who's rage must be managed and avoided and who will has fun playing and laughing with you, is a discovery.  It is emotional to the point that I felt like avoiding it and then it was so fascinatingly truthful in its depth that I could not disengage.  I know more than I did before I experienced this.  I think that was the goal of the man who made it and I know he was sucessful in teaching and sharing somthing from his life.  I was sad and angry durring this experience.  I guess that is the key feature of this game.   It has fastinating visuals and surreal, reality bending puzzles but at its core this is about sharing feelings.  Thank you Papo & Yo.

Papo & Yo is a moving, courageous game. The first thing that struck me about the game was the beautiful and changing landscape of the South American favela that is Quico's playground. The game mechanics center around manipulating this setting in unexpected but mostly intuitive ways. The puzzles are not terribly challenging, but they're also not so easy that they become boring or tedious.\n\nThe real charm and heart of Papo & Yo is the story and the relationships between Quico, Lula, Alejandra, and Monster. It's quite a short game, and the overarching metaphor is only thinly veiled, but the conclusion still left me stunned (and in need of an entire box of tissues). Papo & Yo is an example of how games have the power to do more than simply entertain.

I personally enjoyed Dark Souls and Saints Row too, but I think I can strongly recommend Papo&Yo for different reasons! Try this.

reviewText:
I played this on PS3 a few months ago, and the devs gave me a free key to test 3d support for them.

It's essentially a puzzle-platformer, but to distil it down to its base gameplay elements is to do it a disservice. It's a really affecting story, about a real person's experiences dealing with an abusive parent. That's not something you see very often, and it's a really special experience. The gameplay doesn't always hold up as well as the story - most of the puzzles are reasonably easy, and don't always do as much as they could to establish the characters. But for the most part, it's very well done. An experience well worth having.

The following is all to do with stereo 3d support.

In terms of 3d, this game works really well with only a few minor problems. Probably less than 10 broken shaders in the whole game. You get great toyification effect with the depth and convergence tweaked, and while there are a few issues, they are all pretty minor and easily fixed. Convergence may seem locked at first, but you just need to hold the button down for 20s or so. Hopefully we can see some developer support on the couple of minor issues left. The problems are as follows:

Shadows must be set to low or very low. They do not render correctly on higher settings. Low setting gives blob" shadows
date: very low turns them off. There is a brief cutscene fairly early on where you first become aware of Monster by seeing his shadow as he walks above you. Having shadows off kinda ruins that
recommended: but it's not a big issue anywhere else.\n\nInterface elements (prompts and speech bubbles) render at screen-depth. This isn't much of a problem
helpfulPercent: and so are prompts.\n\nWorld detail must be set to medium. Anything higher and the depth-of field or fog effects cause serious halos. Not sure which effect is causing it
votesHelpful: but medium and below disable it with no other noticeable quality loss.\n\nWhen Monster is in "angry" mode
votesTotal: his flames render differently for each eye
votesFunny: causing a flickering effect. Barely noticeable.\n\nWater shader has massive halos. Fortunately this game doesn't have much water."

reviewText: Papo & Yo is a completely gorgeous game and a lot of fun. The artistic style of this game really deserves to be lauded. There were many screenshot-wothy scenes during the game. There was always something new and interesting to look at.  The puzzles are ok. I only got stuck in two places for any time at all. Still, it was fun to traverse the landscape of the protagonists imagination. The game is only a few hours long, but the time spent on this journey is all quality. I definitely recommend Papo & Yo. Give it a shot.
Definately in the arty" category

recommended: has several interesting puzzle mechanics that aren't repeated

reviewText: Simply amazing! Even if you expect a challenge and finds out the puzzles are rather easy, the game will get you. The plot is as simple as the game itself and still is very deep.\nNot a game for everyone, but definitely for those who enjoy art.

I cannot recommend this game enough. It is a very special puzzle platformer full of childlike wonder that explores the effects of parental abuse. It is a beautiful, healing sort of game with a very emotional ending. It is very personal to me because it actually helped me to heal from my own childhood issues. This is a rare gem in the gaming world that you shouldn't pass up.
Is fun so far, but has tedious moments with the double jump mechanics... you need to do it all the time.

This game redefines the definition of video games. It is art, it is therapy, it is beautiful and heartwrenching. Minority has outdone themselves with this game. As a person who does therapy groups with kids, I wish I could lug my computer to work and allow them to just play the game. I think it would do so much more for them than I could ever even begin to try.
One of the most relaxing and meditative adventures I've ever been on...
Half hour into this game and already I feel its Such a beautiful and creative game with more to it then meets the eye, amazing music also.

What a gem to find. I had looked at the preview movies in the past and it really didn't appeal to me, especially the second movie with the cheesy actors. But the other day I thought I would try it as it was an uninstalled copy that was hanging around from a past humble bundle that I'd bought.

I was expecting to install it, play it for a bit and uninstall it but wow, I had to play it through from start to credits. Soo much attention to detail, some lovely lighting effects, great storyline, amazing sound track, a reason to keep going to find out what happens at the end.

Lots of unexpected quirky ways of looking at the environment around you. A quality game that has some rare first time play goosebump moments. If I had known it was going to be that good I would have bought it ages ago, I think I'll be looking out for more titles by Minority - great work everyone!

A beautiful concept, compelling story and capturing art style. Slightly easy puzzles, but that doesn't detract at all form the story. Thoroughly reccomend.

Papo & Yo is a bit too easy for puzzle fanatics out there, but what it lacks in difficulty it makes up for it in story. Without trying to spoil anything, you are Quico, living in a beautiful, dream-like world with a monster, Papo, who you love very much and keep trying to save. The ending is emotionally touching, but it felt a little bit too obvious, though.

The sound and graphics are lively and dreamy, so despite being simple they fit perfectly in the game world.

There are a couple of annoying glitches though - I got stuck twice between a bridge and a wall and couldn't move and so had to play the whole level 3 times as a result.

Average playtime: about 3 and a half hours.

7/10

Excellent game. One of the best Indie Games I've played.

The ending is just incredible; dark and emotional yet satisfying.

First, I'll say that I enjoy games with immersive atmosphere, story, and a unique artistic vision.  Papo & Yo manages to get all three of those to work together to create a truly unique experience.

Above all else, I would call Papo & Yo a 3D adventure game, and the puzzles are worked into the environment in a way that makes them engaging though not the most innovative in the genre.  That's ok, however, because the real star of this game is the immersive experience of wandering through this fantastical favela, appreciating the colorful artwork, and dissecting the meaning and symbolism behind it all.

I don't know if my interpretation behind some of the imagery was intended by the developers, but when a video game can rise to the level of having multiple interpretations, you know it's something special!  The shift from colorful and sunny to drab and rainy...  The graffiti so intentionally placed in each scene...  The act of moving great buildings and how it relates to both boyhood imagination as well as the main character's role in his troubled father's life...

I experienced no bugs.  The visuals are stunning when using the highest graphical settings.  Look around, pause and enjoy the music, and take it in slowly to make the experience last.

The little gems of creativity, the perfect soundtrack, a story unheard of in the game industry, and the sense of wonder you feel as you explore this world simply cannot be missed by any gamer who believes that games can be art.

This game is a masterpiece! It's the only game I've ever played that left tears in my eyes. Highly personal, and very fun, Papo and Yo is a game about a boy trying to cope with his abusive father. This game opens wounds, but not in a bad way. Instead of determining to make a statement, and pointing it out to you, Papo and Yo immerses you into the story, letting you dictate how you feel about the situations presented.

The gameplay is puzzle based. It's inventive and very imaginative, but not difficult. Do not expect to burnout your brain trying to solve the puzzles. This game is more about the storyline and your personal reaction to it. Your first play through will probably be 2 - 3 hours; so it's not a bad game to play on a lazy afternoon. The graphics are done well with a rich color palette and tones to make you feel you are in the slums. The voice acting is spot on.

I know I'm lavishing over this game, but I really can't say enough good things about it. If there was ever a game I wished everyone would play at least once, it would be Papo and Yo!
This is such a beautiful experience. Unmissable, in my opinion.

On first sight, Papo & Yo could be made for a younger audience. And if you'd leave the story-elements aside, Papo & Yo would be just that. The Gameplay is simple, the mechanics are easy and it is no challenge to beat the game. But Papo & Yo doesn't try to be challenging, it tries to tell a story. The story of a boy who escapes into his own imagination to seek shelter from his alcoholic father, the monster" if you will. And in his imagination
recommended: he tries to "heal" the monster from its addiction to frogs.\nPapo & Yo tells this story in a metaphorical but so profound way
hoursPlayed: sometimes you just need to turn off the game and think about what just happened. As a game Papo & Yo is nothing special
voteText:
but as a tool to express a story it is unique.

8.5/10

PS: The Soundtrack is superb. I bought this game without the Soundtrack and after playing trough Papo & Yo I feel pretty bad about it."

reviewText: This is one of the most beautiful and moving games I have ever played, as well as one of the smartest. A little buggy, but it has an incredibly art style, engaging puzzles, and an excellent soundtrack.
Good stuff. Graphics are beautiful for an indie, love the music and the story is very touching. It isn't very long and is more about story/presentation than challenge, but it works.

This game didn't disappointed me at all. It has a deep story worth telling, showing the life of a boy  dealing with a monster he is trying to save. I played this game basically for the story, i havent seen any other like it. And even if there was, it will not tell it as good as this game.\n\nThe puzzles are pretty easy, the creativeness of the game is awesome.

Papo and Yo has one of the most unique and touching stories that I've found in a video game. It's use fantastic use of metaphor to tell it's story is not to be undermined. It's beautiful visuals and it's enjoyable soundtraack also add to the experience significantly. However Papo and Yo is also one of the most tedious games I've played, and although it's a mere three hours long, I still found myself bored with the gameplay. The puzzels in the game are not challenging and the most difficult will simply have you running around for a minute or two until you stumble upon the solution. This makes Papo and Yo extremely difficult to recommend. Buy it on sale if you're interested.

Papo & Yo was clearly a very personal project to its creators, and that shines through in the way the story slowly develops. It's a surreal journey through the eyes and imaginative interpretation of the child protagonist, but still treats the main subject matter with dignity. On top of this there's some fantastic level design, making great use of the dreamlike world to present each puzzle.

This is an all around stunning game. From the level design, texture quality, and unique animations to sound design to the beautifully crafted narrative of which the game is focused, nothing fails to impress. The gameplay is based around puzzles/platforming in a three-dimensional environment. The gameplay does not present much of a challenge but the controls are solid and intuitive, playing great with gamepad or keyboard/mouse. The music and ambient environmental sounds are immersive and calming, allowing for a stark contrast when the narrative calls for it. The narrative deals with themes of addiction, abuse, and denial through excellent use of imagery and symbolism.\nEverything fits together amazingly well in this game. It's rare to find a game that so excellently parses mature themes without resorting to mindless violence. I've been playing games for fifteen years, and I can honestly say this is one of the best. I bought it on sale not knowing what to expect and having beaten it, I gladly would have paid many times over the price for such an experience.
The gameplay is fun and god the grafititi artwork everywhere is amazing!
Fantastic game. The puzzles were pretty simplistic, but the storyline was so good. I enjoyed the environment and music quite a bit also. I would recommend this game to anyone.

At around 3 hours of game time with little to no replayability, Papo & Yo is more of a literary vignette. Which suits it just fine. You're not getting a game out of this, you're getting a story told in an interesting and compelling way. I do feel that the true meaning behind the Monster should be less obvious during the course of the game and the $15 is a bit steep, but this is a worthy buy on sale for an evening of thoughtful entertainment.
Really charming with imaginative puzzles and visuals and an important underlying story. Totally underrated.
A good short Puzzle/Platformer game with pretty good graphics for being an ''Indie'' game. Though, many people might not like the game because of the true meaning it has.

Loved this, in terms of gameplay it's very simple there really wasn't anything you could say was challenging there's no penalty for failure, no healthpoints, no real enemies, there's platforming but it's extremely simple. It's quite short, the graphics are nice but they're not spectacular.\n\nOn the other hand it has an poignant very well told story though the ending is a little too blatant in that it just flat out states a lot of the subtext. That said the story is one of the best I've seen in a videogame, if not the best. If you were to compare this to any game it'd be Ico (though it has quite a different feel and story to it) and that's got to be reason enough to play it.

Truly a fantastic adventure game! Papo & Yo will not only present you with interesting puzzles and fun gameplay, but also challenge you to look inward to the demons we all battle throughout life (and more importantly the places we go to escape them).

This is a game about a boy named Quico and his seemingly magical action figure Lula, as well as a giant - and normally docile - beast named Monster. As Quico, you will explore various facets of the dream-like favela he escapes to, where the laws of reality itself bend to the whim of one little boy.

The core gameplay focuses on solving environmental puzzles, many of which involve magic chalk-like drawings on the walls and floors of buildings that let you manipulate this strange and beautiful world in a variety of different ways. There is also some light platforming and some interesting mechanics which involve Lula, who straddles your backside like a knapsack and acts as a sort of jetpack that can also carry out some basic commands (such as flipping switches for you at a distance). Monster will also play a big part (no pun intended) in solving a lot of said puzzles and offers his own unique mechanics; when he is asleep his massive gut can be used as a trampoline of sorts and of course that brute strength of his also comes in handy! You have to be careful, however, as Monster also has an unhealthy addiction to poisonous frogs which cause him to burst into flames and go on a rampage!

All in all this is a refreshing take on 3D puzzle-platformers, that also reminds us just how beautiful and robust the Unreal Engine can still be when in the right hands.

The game isn't too long, or challenging, but it has beautiful audio and visual design. The subject of the game is also something different for a change, something personal and real. It is a great game if you are into something more about expression/narrative/art than challenge. I'd recommend the soundtrack edition, while you're at it.\n\nHowever, there are hidden collectables you can grab during your second playthrough, if you choose to do so.

I got to a point where the game almost destroyed me, more then any other piece of media has done so far.\nI also only just finished it and with some of the raw feelings still lingering I want to laud the creator of this for what he did and punch him for what he made me do.\nEarlier though, at the time, in the moment, the priorities were quite the reverse.
It's a bit short at about 3-4 hours of play, but I found it charming, frightening, and a little bit sad. Worth a look in for a different kind of narrative in games.

An engrossing emotional story set in a platform puzzler. I really enjoyed the blend of story and gameplay. Yes the game has a very obvious point about dealing with alcoholism and its effects on families, but that drives the story and the relationships between the characters quite well. I strongly recommend this game to anyone who wants to try something a little different and something extremely engrossing. I was so engrossed i completed the game in one sitting, which is about 3.5 hours if you take your time

Wow, this game is so interesting, and i like it's mysterious content. The Graphics are gorgeous and beautiful. Controlling your main character may feel like it's too small, (well, because you are a little kid) but it feels nice. The story of this game is quite not bad at all, but there is a small lack in it, the whole gameplay was too short. Anyway, i'd recomend this game for cool adventure seekers.

Ico-esque adventure game where your companion is [very explicitly] a big, hulking metaphor for the game creator's abusive, alcoholic father. Subtle this game was not ... but it *was* unique, and in the end it did have a real effect on me. I'm very glad to have played it, but it's heavy enough that I'm unlikely to play through it again.

Strengths: Really striking and original visuals / artistic direction, superb music, refreshing protagonist [the opposite of the powerfulwhitemale we so often see in games]. Short length, ~3.5 hours [a big plus given my schedule].

Weaknesses: The gameplay itself is a bit repetitive [though the constant introduction of new visuals and mechanics does liven things up]. The puzzles are trivial [this is an adventure game, not a puzzle game]. Some minor control+camera wonkiness. Complete lack of subtlety in hitting you with the game's central metaphor [this game's creator is making a very personal, cathartic game.]
holy criminy this is so so good. so good. perfect.
dont let this game on sale get away, its a great story (so far) and it reminds me of ICO. it certianly is worth 3.00 and a plus if you have a 360 controller.
Love it captivating beautiful lovely story buy it 5 hours great entertainment.

I recommend this game to everyone that has steam. It's probably one of the best games I have ever played, it took me 3 hours to complete but those 3 hours were so good that it looked like you played it for 1 hour. Beautiful music, beautiful graphics, beautiful storyline and a very sad end..  10/10 would recommend

Deep storytelling.\n7/10
Wow. I thought It'll be bad at the start. But this amazed me. The sacrifice ... So worth the price.
Most superb game story I've seen in years. And the visuals are incredible. A MUST play!

One of the most artistically superior games I've ever seen.  The entire game is a metaphor for a very real and very serious social problem, and the game does a very good job telling its message without beating you over the head with it.  A beautiful story about the power of childhood imagination and family life with an abusive parent.

This game is worth every single penny !! I havent played such a game in a very long time. Entertaining gameplay with amazing soundtrack and a sad story in a background and breathtaking views = amazing game
This is one of the most beatyful games i ever played in my life. With great puzzles and an very symbolic story, that tells you alot about the developer who created the game. A must play

Loved this, in terms of gameplay it's very simple there really wasn't anything you could say was challenging there's no penalty for failure, no healthpoints, no real enemies, there's platforming but it's extremely simple. It's quite short, the graphics are nice but they're not spectacular.\n\nOn the other hand it has an poignant very well told story though the ending is a little too blatant in that it just flat out states a lot of the subtext. That said the story is one of the best I've seen in a videogame, if not the best. If you were to compare this to any game it'd be Ico (though it has quite a different feel and story to it) and that's got to be reason enough to play it.

Papo & Yo is a metaphorical story played out within a child's imaginative mind. Adhering to its theme, the gameplay and puzzles are simple and childlike. The story progresses, driven by the nostalgic innocence of childhood, and ultimately unfolds out into a darker, more mature theme.\n\nRecommended to those who can appreciate an emotionally engaging storyline, vibrant visuals, and a uniquely magical soundtrack.

Okay. Papo & Yo.

My first attraction to the game came with its visuals. The bright, colorful design of the favelas instantly caught my attention in a market saturated by grays and sepias. It stood out, it was new, it was charming. I picked it up, played it for a short while, and then set it down for a week. This should not speak poorly for the game but, rather, for my lack of attention. It took a little bit to get started. But when it did get started, oh man. It got started.

I have since finished the game, and I can now safely call it one of the most important games I have ever played. Not because of anything that it does in the gameplay that is new. The gameplay is only ever average, an affair of finding gears to push and plungers to pull. It has its difficulties - the frame rate will sometimes skip for no reason, and the platforming elements feel strange. Quico, the protagonist, has a strange weight to him, making jumping a bit of an unusual effort. The gameplay is the weakest part of this game.

But it is everywhere else that it shines. It can be terribly dazzling when it wants to be, offering a magically real landscape of favelas that twist and turn and defy gravity, and houses that walk on legs made of chalk, and an enormous pink monster with sun-cracked skin and a dangerous addiction to tropical frogs.

And for every wonderful moment there is a counterpoint, a realization that this experience is inspired by Creative Director / Writer Vander Caballero's relationship with his alcoholic father. Later in the game Monster finally gets his hands on one of those irresistable little frogs, and gobbles it up. He is instantly wreathed in red flames, and he turns on you with a stomach-gnashing roar. Poor little Quico suddenly seems very small against the rampaging Monster, very fragile.

The story's focus is on Quico's quest to cure Monster. You go on a journey to find a shaman, aided by a mysterious girl and an endearing toy robot named Lula, and of course Monster. Sometimes things go quite well. Sometimes they go very wrong.

There are moments were Papo & Yo is absolutely childlike in its wonder.There are moments that are dark and threatening. And there are moments where you have to do things that are painful and liberating. This is a game of powerful, startling, painful moments, strung along to lure you deeper into its narrative.

I feel Papo & Yo is best experienced in a single sitting. The puzzles never become inhibitingly difficult, and you can finish it in about 2 - 4 hours. Which, honestly, you should.

If you want to know more, read the reviews put out by Rock Paper Shotgun and the New York Times.

reviewText: I really really like basically everything about Papo & Yo.
Good puzzler. Very nice graphics. Not too hard. Very simple controls.

A beautiful puzzle game set in Latin-America. Not only does it take an elegant slice from such an exotic culture, it grounds itself with a wonderous human element that is not only intriguing, but violently sickening, depressing and so absolutely disgusting I wouldn't touch it with a pole as long as a human intestine.
Interesting game, story is really touching in places but gameplay isn't anything special.

A fabulously creative and fun game. Wonderful to play with my daughter. With an imagantive storyline, great visuals and audio, and simple but elegant controls, Papo & Yo is loads of fun and a great introduction to third person games and puzzle solving. Definitely a strong recommendation for anyone looking for something fun and a little bit unique.
This game is a game made so a guy could work through his isssues with his father. Theres lots of fun little mechanics and its worth playing. Only a few hours long.
Half hour into this game and already I feel its Such a beautiful and creative game with more to it then meets the eye, amazing music also.

What a gem to find. I had looked at the preview movies in the past and it really didn't appeal to me, especially the second movie with the cheesy actors. But the other day I thought I would try it as it was an uninstalled copy that was hanging around from a past humble bundle that I'd bought.

I was expecting to install it, play it for a bit and uninstall it but wow, I had to play it through from start to credits. Soo much attention to detail, some lovely lighting effects, great storyline, amazing sound track, a reason to keep going to find out what happens at the end.

Lots of unexpected quirky ways of looking at the environment around you. A quality game that has some rare first time play goosebump moments. If I had known it was going to be that good I would have bought it ages ago, I think I'll be looking out for more titles by Minority - great work everyone!
This is absolutley beautifull, worth the buy but maybe at a sale, but still nice story, graphics and soundtrack

Papo & Yo is worth playing. Though it suffers from some execution problems, the emotional impact of the story is where the game shines. I beat the game in under three hours, as the puzzles within aren't complex and most of the time taken to complete them is due to plodding, basic platformer demands.\nWhat's truly refreshing about Papo & Yo is that is breaks free from the tradition of the vanilla white male protagonist and challenges us with a deep, emotional story hidden underneath a richly imagined world.
Very nice game. You can enjoy this beautiful game even with gamepad !\nAnd there is one thing, that you will not expect - the ending.

This game is so cute! I've only played the first little bit, but the graphics are amazing and so is the setting. The puzzles are neat, and are solved by moving entire buildings around! It feels like I'm playing in a child's imagination. Also there are giant frogs you can pick up and run around with. They have big floppy feet and had me giggling like mad.
You can pick up a frog and he looks like he likes being held but then you have to put him down eventually which sucks.
Fantastic game. Really spoke to me since I have been through a similiar situation with home life. That aside, the gameplay and puzzles are great. Worth every penny.

This game was the gone home before gone home. This games tells the the player a tragic story by having you play as a the son or victim of this tragedy. As you progess through the narrative... it becomes clear that this story is less about the art style and gameplay but more about telling the story of dealing with tragedy... that we don't often see in games nowadays.

Don't exoect instant gratification or a great payoff. Invest your time in the story and you will come away feeling a lot better for having played this game. I remember pre-ordering this game and I normally do not pre-order a game of this type... but something compelled me to do so. I still can't find what truly compelled me because it is hard to put into words how satisfied I am for having played this game.

There are very few games that I can hold the narrative and objective of the game in such high regard. This is one of them.
Pretty awesome game. beautiful music, simple game play with fun things to do..\n

I personally enjoyed Dark Souls and Saints Row too, but I think I can strongly recommend Papo&Yo for different reasons! Try this.

The game plays out like a puzzle/platformer with fairly simple game mechanics and challanges, but the story is told beautifully and the surreal environment ties the whole game together.

It's pretty short, only lasting about 3-4 hours on the first playthrough but it is a joy to play and anybody who has had someone close to them with a history of substance abuse can relate to the story.

I believe it's worth full price if you're into games that rely on their story like Brothers: A Tale Of Two Sons, and it's definitely worth picking up when it's on sale for everyone else.

I wasn't expecting the game to be this good, when I booted it for the first time, but I just went with it and had fun! It's got great movement and interestic mechanics!

The whole game is vibrant and beautiful, and it's a metaphor for something else, wich is revealed in the end.

Really liked the game, takes about 4 hours to finish. I really liked how they used so few lines, you really have to play to the end.

Excellent artistic and music direction. Simple yet deep story telling. While the puzzles are never anything too difficult, they're a great breath of fresh air. If you have an afternoon free and feel like trying a new 3d platformer/puzzle game, definitely give this game a go.

Surprisingly amazing game, very nice and laid back with interesting although fairly simple puzzles. The game takes on the main protagonist of Papo and delves into the true meaning of what the game is about. Its interesting as not many games are able to take on adult content such as this one and provide real impact especially one on an emotional level without just showing something in full blatant force. It feels like the game takes on adult themes in a very  subtle way which makes it more interesting as you play different parts of the game and wonder what each part truly means. The game is fairly short where I finished it in one day which feels really good as its not long enough to drag on and also shows the main focus which is a lot of story, puzzles and plat forming. For an indie game I didn't expect too much and so was pleasantly surprised to find out how great the game is. As a puzzle game its also quite interesting although can be quite simple at times. The best part of the simplicity of the puzzle is that it feels like you're always moving forward kind of like if you start a good run and you don't really want to stop. This creates a good flow to the game as I never felt that I had to just stop and think, or get annoyed and trying random things until something happened. I would definitely give it a recommendation, especially if you're looking for a fairly short and intriguing indie game.

A violent story told through the innocent eyes of a creative child, with good music, great odd looking puzzles, intriguing characters and astonishing sceneries.

I simply loved to play this game. It surprised and captured all my attention with it's creativity and originality and the fact that its story had a deeper and real meaning made it even more special.

One thing I must add is the fact that the game, however complex it is, is still simple enough for my four year old sister to play, like and understand (with a little help here and there). She enjoys the game a lot and understood the real problem behind the game's ficticious story without scarring her while still having fun.

Well that was emotional...

Essentially a series of spacial puzzles set in a 3D world, you play the part of Quico as he seeks to remove his friend Monster's anger by taking him to a shaman.  As we progress we see that Monster is something of a metaphor for Quico's sad past.

The story is delivered with confidence and impact.  The puzzles throughout, whilst not difficult, require some thought and a fair amount of spacial awareness.

All in all you're looking at 4 hours of fantastic playtime with a satisfying ending.  A second playthrough includes a now-unlocked side mission in which you must locate a collection of dolls, giving you a fine reason for a second playthrough.

I had one small problem with the game crashing.  A search about found it's not an uncommon issue, but no-one seemed to have an answer that worked for me - but sure enough verifying the cache in Steam fixed it for me and it didn't happen again.

This is an odd game to recommend because to explain what it is is to spoil it a bit.

Basically it is a puzzle game and a short one at that; it took me about 3 and a half hours to complete it one time. Personally I'm glad I played it but if I hadn't got it on sale for ¬£8 my view might be different.

It's a very refreshing game, making a point while giving you some really cool puzzles. it tries to engage you in the 'story' and, for me, did this quite nicely with subtle metaphors and imagery. Different people will experience this game differently, if you want a game that is just about the action or puzzles, this might disappoint, but I found it to be an incredibly chilled out game, you can't die and the music is very well done, fitting the atmosphere without becoming repetative. The graphics on the trailer look really poor, but I was surprised by how nice it looked.

When I finished the game I felt like it could have been longer with more puzzles, but at the same time, I played it through in one night and it was a cool little game that kept me entertained start to finish. In some ways, the fact that it's short makes it more enjoyable.

If you can get it on sale then I recommend it, it's very different and if you can think of it loosely like paying for a film, in this case a puzzle 'experience', then it's well worth ¬£8.

reviewText:
This game takes you in a world where physics as we know them dont exist. It just plays with the world and its setting... and with you. The puzzles are pretty easy but I didnt buy the game because of them - more likely because of the story.

At the first sight this game looks pretty easy to understand. There's a monster and it likes to eat or play football with you! But only as long as you can prevent him from eating those frogs...
I won't tell any further because the emotions and feelings you experience during the game will be more intense if you dont know that much about the story. A story that many people may have lived through...

That last chapter/level (call it what you want) definitely is one of the most emotional things I've ever seen in gaming/movie history.

Gameplay: 9/10
Storyline: 9/10
Graphics: 8/10
SoundTrack: 9/10
Overall: 8.75/10


The game puts players in the shoes of Quico, a boy whose complex fantasies are loosely tied with the real world.  Think the dilapidated, South American version of the Hundred Acre Woods.  Quico is looking for a way to cure his monster friend, as every time he eats poison frogs(alcohol), he goes on a rampage, destroying all in his path.  Otherwise, the monster is a peaceful being, and even saves your skin if you mess up in certain puzzles.  At its core, Papo & Yo has a metaphorical, psuedo-autobiographical story that was inspired by the childhood experiences of Minority‚Äôs creative director, Vander Caballero.

A truly heartfelt experience metaphorically encapsulating the struggles of addiction and its effects upon family members through the eyes of an innocent child. This is gaming as an art form and a medium of expression. Geared more towards the literary analysis types and less to the shoot-em-up CoD-bro gamers. I only regret paying so little for it.
I didn't know a game could be this beautiful
This quirky little game really left an impression on me. I reccomend it. it has a nice story. definately not GOTY or whatever but its okay :D really enjoyed it personally.

I loved this game. The increasingly surreal environment and the way you manipulate the world is gorgeous. The gameplay is very intuitive, the puzzles are simple yet very satisfying. The bright, childish environment and fun gameplay contrasts strongly with the dark, sad underlying story to create a great experience. It is relatively short but I enjoyed every minute of it.

Well, my first ever steam review.  I HAD to review this.  A of hardcore gamer for over 30 years, this is the only one that warrents my time writing and promoting.  This game is beutiful.  It is really clever, artistic, imaginative, visually stunning, charming, wierd, warm, cold, gripping, mesmerising,  refreshing, and has a deep emotional story line like no other game before it  (or probably ever will ).  And on top of  this the gameplay is excellent,  the puzzles are clever, amusing and addictive.   A lot of care and thought has gone into this game.  Its a true escapist adventure.   Its on a par with A Tale of Two Brothers, another meticulously crafted, emotional and beautiful adventure puzzler game.  I found both games evoked similar emotions when playing.   I'd rate TOTB as the greatest game I've ever played (from from all genres).  Its hard to explain why other than the powerful emotions it evoked.  This game nearly steals that title for the same reasons but not quite.   I would definately rate this as the most original game I've ever played. Worth every penny. Truly Stunning.  Basically you just have to play it!   Limbo and Machinarium, great as they are, have been bumped down the list.\n

It's an interesting adventure / puzzle game.

The environment just looks fantastic and the story is at first abit straight. But then, there is alot more going on with the story and you'll always wonder what you'll learn in the next chapter. The puzzles are sadly abit easy. But overall, it's a nice game and you should check it out.

And also any 'Inception' fans should check the game out too. :)
This is, without a doubt, one of the best games I have ever played.  It takes a lot for a game to make me shed a tear.  Papo & Yo did it like it was their job; a job they did very well..*sniff*
It has a few problems but overall Papa & Yo is an intelligent and well put together video game.

Absolutely fantastic game. Beautiful and touching on many levels. The story and landscape is worth experiencing just for their own worth, but this is also very well built as a modern puzzle game, where you need to find ways to change the world around you to progress through the game.
A fun game with a serious underlying message.\n\nThe artwork on the walls throughout the game is phenomenal!
Wonderful game, the pictures and the story together with sound and music create an amazing atmosphere!
One of the most inventive and interesting games I've ever played, and incredibly powerful.
I thought by the title it was a game about rappers not a boy who falls a sleep and dreams about the dreamtime\n
Just played the first 45 minutes or so, but this game is great so far. So well done and very nice music!

I played this on PS3 a few months ago, and the devs gave me a free key to test 3d support for them.

It's essentially a puzzle-platformer, but to distil it down to its base gameplay elements is to do it a disservice. It's a really affecting story, about a real person's experiences dealing with an abusive parent. That's not something you see very often, and it's a really special experience. The gameplay doesn't always hold up as well as the story - most of the puzzles are reasonably easy, and don't always do as much as they could to establish the characters. But for the most part, it's very well done. An experience well worth having.

The following is all to do with stereo 3d support.

In terms of 3d, this game works really well with only a few minor problems. Probably less than 10 broken shaders in the whole game. You get great toyification effect with the depth and convergence tweaked, and while there are a few issues, they are all pretty minor and easily fixed. Convergence may seem locked at first, but you just need to hold the button down for 20s or so. Hopefully we can see some developer support on the couple of minor issues left. The problems are as follows:

Shadows must be set to low or very low. They do not render correctly on higher settings. Low setting gives blob" shadows
date: very low turns them off. There is a brief cutscene fairly early on where you first become aware of Monster by seeing his shadow as he walks above you. Having shadows off kinda ruins that
recommended: but it's not a big issue anywhere else.\n\nInterface elements (prompts and speech bubbles) render at screen-depth. This isn't much of a problem
helpfulPercent: and so are prompts.\n\nWorld detail must be set to medium. Anything higher and the depth-of field or fog effects cause serious halos. Not sure which effect is causing it
votesHelpful: but medium and below disable it with no other noticeable quality loss.\n\nWhen Monster is in "angry" mode
votesTotal: his flames render differently for each eye
votesFunny: causing a flickering effect. Barely noticeable.\n\nWater shader has massive halos. Fortunately this game doesn't have much water."

First, I'll say that I enjoy games with immersive atmosphere, story, and a unique artistic vision.  Papo & Yo manages to get all three of those to work together to create a truly unique experience.

Above all else, I would call Papo & Yo a 3D adventure game, and the puzzles are worked into the environment in a way that makes them engaging though not the most innovative in the genre.  That's ok, however, because the real star of this game is the immersive experience of wandering through this fantastical favela, appreciating the colorful artwork, and dissecting the meaning and symbolism behind it all.

I don't know if my interpretation behind some of the imagery was intended by the developers, but when a video game can rise to the level of having multiple interpretations, you know it's something special!  The shift from colorful and sunny to drab and rainy...  The graffiti so intentionally placed in each scene...  The act of moving great buildings and how it relates to both boyhood imagination as well as the main character's role in his troubled father's life...

I experienced no bugs.  The visuals are stunning when using the highest graphical settings.  Look around, pause and enjoy the music, and take it in slowly to make the experience last.

The little gems of creativity, the perfect soundtrack, a story unheard of in the game industry, and the sense of wonder you feel as you explore this world simply cannot be missed by any gamer who believes that games can be art.

A barely disguised allegory, the game is occasionally overbearing in its message.  The puzzling and platforming is usually just this side of tedious.  Nevertheless I love this game as it's a perfect example of the interactive form being the correct choice for telling a particular story.  Fear, frustration, and the magical beliefs of a child thinking he can change what is through the few options available to him make for a near seamless intertwining of feeling, meaning, and gameplay.  There were times when I refused to do what the game asked of me; other times it gave me chills as I tried to process how I felt about what was happening.  The art and music are glorious.  Well worth the 3 hours it will take to play to completion.
I was able to guess the big reveal" of the ending from pretty much the very beginning of the game

One of the most creative & imaginative games I've ever played. Keep in mind that this game is not so much about the gameplay or puzzle mechanics as it is about storytelling a person's life experiences. The use of visual metaphors to reflect his personal life is perhaps as yet unmatched by any other storyteller.

If you want your heart strings pulled, play this game until the end. Wow.\n\nPapo & Yo is based on the monsters that live within. It's a sad reality that is shown in the fantasy world of a little boy named Quico, who escapes the troubled life of his alcoholic father. Quico gets help along the way from his little robot Lula and a girl named Alejandra who is quite mischievous at times. Monster, who Quico thinks is his best friend, can either help, or hinder his progression, depending on if he consumes any frogs. The game play is pretty straightforward but offers beautiful visuals, especially in its art. I wish this game was a bit longer, however it is definitely worth a play if you are into visuals and a solid story that will evoke emotion.

reviewText: Papo Y Yo gives you freedom to explore, and even the power to change an incredibly beautiful environment in Brazil. The underlying message is profound, both deeply sad and powerfully hopeful. 9.5/10.

Papo & Yo is a moving, courageous game. The first thing that struck me about the game was the beautiful and changing landscape of the South American favela that is Quico's playground. The game mechanics center around manipulating this setting in unexpected but mostly intuitive ways. The puzzles are not terribly challenging, but they're also not so easy that they become boring or tedious.\n\nThe real charm and heart of Papo & Yo is the story and the relationships between Quico, Lula, Alejandra, and Monster. It's quite a short game, and the overarching metaphor is only thinly veiled, but the conclusion still left me stunned (and in need of an entire box of tissues). Papo & Yo is an example of how games have the power to do more than simply entertain.

Highly recommend this game for a single playthrough. It is short but very beautiful. It is also very sad, so be prepared for the feels. The subject matter is something that I am not super familar with myself but I found very moving none the less. The ending is a bit unsettling to me but, overall, the game had a great narritive that isn't always expressed in words.

Well, my first ever steam review.  I HAD to review this.  A of hardcore gamer for over 30 years, this is the only one that warrents my time writing and promoting.  This game is beutiful.  It is really clever, artistic, imaginative, visually stunning, charming, wierd, warm, cold, gripping, mesmerising,  refreshing, and has a deep emotional story line like no other game before it  (or probably ever will ).  And on top of  this the gameplay is excellent,  the puzzles are clever, amusing and addictive.   A lot of care and thought has gone into this game.  Its a true escapist adventure.   Its on a par with A Tale of Two Brothers, another meticulously crafted, emotional and beautiful adventure puzzler game.  I found both games evoked similar emotions when playing.   I'd rate TOTB as the greatest game I've ever played (from from all genres).  Its hard to explain why other than the powerful emotions it evoked.  This game nearly steals that title for the same reasons but not quite.   I would definately rate this as the most original game I've ever played. Worth every penny. Truly Stunning.  Basically you just have to play it!   Limbo and Machinarium, great as they are, have been bumped down the list.\n

I don't like platformer.  I don't like jumping puzzles.  I especially don't like timing puzzles.  I'm not very good at any of those.  Because of that, I should not have liked this game.  But I did.  I liked this game a lot.

The gameplay was simple enough that I could play through it without getting seriously frustrated by my lack of skill; but still challenging enough not to be boring.   The puzzles that did not involve jumping and timing were very clever, but for the most part still logical and intuitive once you got into the flow of the game.  There were a few odd moments where the puzzles did not make a whole lot of sense, and I was force to rely on a walkthrough; but very few (unlike so many modern puzzle games, where randomness is used as a cheap and easy substitute for cleverness).  The mechanics of the game are very entertaining in themselves, particularly once Lulu is introduced.

The game design is beautiful; and the creators use of an uncommon setting was brilliant.  The third-world backdrop meshed very well with the fantastical elements; creating a seamless world with it's own unique and readily-identifiable logic.  The artwork is stunning, and the inclusion of works by actual environmental artists nothing short of amazing.  The similar use of third-world characters, rather than white Europeans or stereotypical fantasy creatures is similarly inspiring.  The music is beautiful, and in spots almost breathtaking, wonderfully blending traditional and orchestral sounds.  Atmospheric and fun at the same time.

I would be hard pressed to find any flaws in the game.  If I did, I would say that parts of the ending felt a little out of place.  Some of the scenes and actions didn't make quite as much sense as they could have, and the symbolism is a bit heavyhanded; but that's still a fairly minor quibble.   The game is a bit shorter than most of its type; but too much longer and it would have started to drag.  The pacing never leave it feeling too long or too short.

One warning is that the background story that emerges from the game is disturbing, becoming increasingly so the closer it gets to the end.  This is ultimately a story of addiction and child abuse; and is accordingly dark and sad.  Fortunately, the writers do not beat the player over the head with moralizing; and manage to balance the darkness with a keen sense of human resilience.

I cannot recommend this game enough.  I picked it up at a huge discount during one of Steam's big sales; but would can easily recommend getting it even at full price.

This game plays like a third person Portal meets Inception (you'll know what I mean if you play it). A gorgeous looking puzzler that I can strongly recommend.

The puzzle platforming is simple and engaging.  But that isn't the draw.  This is the kind of cathartic art that someone creates in therapy.  It's like a black and white painting of a beaten child in a dark corner under a spotlight.  It is blunt, it is abrupt and it is unsubtle, but it will evoke a powerful emmotional response.

Papo & Yo is about as close to a breakthrough where games transcend art/entertainment, and become a catharsis for personal emotions.  This truly feels like the the creator of the game wants you to relive some tragic events that shaped his life, and asks you to participate in a safe and engaging way.  At times, it takes the horrible and makes something beautiful out of it.  A must play.

This is a very touching and thoughtful game. This game is incredible, at first i thought it weren't going to be that good. Well blimey i was wrong. The story is so enjoyable and moving. I'm about halfway through and i have loved every bit of it.

If this game is on sale, then I would recommend getting it. It can be finished in about 3 hours, so the price tag is a little bit high if you pay full price.

Anyway, the game is an environment based puzzle platformer with a story that both draws you in and screws with your mind. You think it's just a game that takes place inside a child's imagination, where everything is cheerful and happy, but it kinda isn't. I won't spoil it but by the end of the game, you realise that the environment the game takes place in actually reflects the rather  grim story. Definitely one to make you think.

The gameplay is quite inventive too. The environment itself pretty much bends (literally in some cases) to allow you to proceed. It is well and truly the product of a creative mind and the way you have to complete the puzzles may be simple in terms of what you have to do, but it sure as hell takes a level of thought sometimes. Thankfully, there are hint boxes for the more complex puzzles in the game. I did enjoy playing it.

Way better than people give it credit for. It's true that some of the puzzles are obvious yet tedious to complete, but the design of the puzzles is creative, the art style is great, and the characters are compelling. If you're not that interested, I would probably give it a pass or wait for a sale, but if you're interested then just get it. The flaws don't run the experience in my opinion.

Surprisingly good puzzle game with a poignant story set in a surreal Brazillian shanty town. A kid uses his imagination to cope with having an alcoholic father, which translates into having a robot for a jetpack and the ability to levitate buildings with telekinesis... which is pretty cool.

A mesmerizing approach to a poetic entity that leaves you with a sense of understanding about a character through metaphors.  This story will strike at your heart in a meaningful way, in which it will leave you awed at how well the world and events are put together. Aside from the simplistic puzzles and mishaps where you need to repeat yourself in a game of trial and error in some parts, you begin to establish a relationship with each character without need for many words.\nThe symbolic metaphors, masterful soundtrack pieces, and seeing the dark side of the story will most likely hit you at its prime, the very core of your heart, and jerk a tear right out of your existence.

An attractive, touching game about a child trying to make sense of the chaotic world around him.  While the game has a childlike flavor, the issues the game touches upon are not simply for children.  While not technically challenging, the game's message will linger with you after you've solved your last puzzle.

reviewText: Short, simple and poignant. Great game. Highly recommend.

At its core, Papo & Yo is a reasonably simple puzzle-platformer, that takes around 3-4 hours to complete (with perhaps another hour or two if you feel like going for all the achievements).

The imaginative and magical take on the already colourful environments (including some awesome artwork on the buildings and walls) are fantastic though and the soundtrack really adds to the whole experience.
However the metaphorical storyline is where it shines through, delivering a mature and poignant plotline.

reviewText: The best game i've played all year. Not a lot to say, it was beautifully done. The music was elegant (going to buy the OST), the gameplay was fluid and enjoyable and the storyline (hit's ya right in the feels) was a breath of fresh air. I wish I had played this earlier, but am glad that I had a chance to experience it.

This is a complicated review to write lots of good and a bit of bad. TL;Dr: dont expect a lot of replay value out of this one but if your are looking for a stylish platformer/puzzler it's worth the buy.

the good:
-great story with a very personal feel
-nice enviroments with great cohesion
-fairly well programmed controls and camera follow
-over all unique and quite creative
-attention to detail and a well thought out surreal theme

the bad:
-quite short could easily be wrapped in one sitting
-some of the puzzle mechanics get a bit tired by the end
-not a lot of replay value here (which is made more apparent by the 3 hour playtime)
-the character move speed could have been a bit faster and the jumps feel a bit clunky at times.
-the story gets to be a bit too on the nose by the time it wraps up, but it certainly does clarify things for those that missed it.

It's really hard to rate this title over all, as a game by way of mechanics and difficulty its a 5/10 - but combined with the story and over all feel it's easly an 8 if not 9/10.

On first sight, Papo & Yo could be made for a younger audience. And if you'd leave the story-elements aside, Papo & Yo would be just that. The Gameplay is simple, the mechanics are easy and it is no challenge to beat the game. But Papo & Yo doesn't try to be challenging, it tries to tell a story. The story of a boy who escapes into his own imagination to seek shelter from his alcoholic father, the monster" if you will. And in his imagination
recommended: he tries to "heal" the monster from its addiction to frogs.\nPapo & Yo tells this story in a metaphorical but so profound way
hoursPlayed: sometimes you just need to turn off the game and think about what just happened. As a game Papo & Yo is nothing special
voteText:
but as a tool to express a story it is unique.

8.5/10

PS: The Soundtrack is superb. I bought this game without the Soundtrack and after playing trough Papo & Yo I feel pretty bad about it."

reviewText: This is one of the most beautiful and moving games I have ever played, as well as one of the smartest. A little buggy, but it has an incredibly art style, engaging puzzles, and an excellent soundtrack.
Good stuff. Graphics are beautiful for an indie, love the music and the story is very touching. It isn't very long and is more about story/presentation than challenge, but it works.

This game didn't disappointed me at all. It has a deep story worth telling, showing the life of a boy  dealing with a monster he is trying to save. I played this game basically for the story, i havent seen any other like it. And even if there was, it will not tell it as good as this game.\n\nThe puzzles are pretty easy, the creativeness of the game is awesome.
Really charming with imaginative puzzles and visuals and an important underlying story. Totally underrated.
A good short Puzzle/Platformer game with pretty good graphics for being an ''Indie'' game. Though, many people might not like the game because of the true meaning it has.

Loved this, in terms of gameplay it's very simple there really wasn't anything you could say was challenging there's no penalty for failure, no healthpoints, no real enemies, there's platforming but it's extremely simple. It's quite short, the graphics are nice but they're not spectacular.\n\nOn the other hand it has an poignant very well told story though the ending is a little too blatant in that it just flat out states a lot of the subtext. That said the story is one of the best I've seen in a videogame, if not the best. If you were to compare this to any game it'd be Ico (though it has quite a different feel and story to it) and that's got to be reason enough to play it.

Well that was emotional...

Essentially a series of spacial puzzles set in a 3D world, you play the part of Quico as he seeks to remove his friend Monster's anger by taking him to a shaman.  As we progress we see that Monster is something of a metaphor for Quico's sad past.

The story is delivered with confidence and impact.  The puzzles throughout, whilst not difficult, require some thought and a fair amount of spacial awareness.

All in all you're looking at 4 hours of fantastic playtime with a satisfying ending.  A second playthrough includes a now-unlocked side mission in which you must locate a collection of dolls, giving you a fine reason for a second playthrough.

I had one small problem with the game crashing.  A search about found it's not an uncommon issue, but no-one seemed to have an answer that worked for me - but sure enough verifying the cache in Steam fixed it for me and it didn't happen again.

This is an odd game to recommend because to explain what it is is to spoil it a bit.

Basically it is a puzzle game and a short one at that; it took me about 3 and a half hours to complete it one time. Personally I'm glad I played it but if I hadn't got it on sale for ¬£8 my view might be different.

It's a very refreshing game, making a point while giving you some really cool puzzles. it tries to engage you in the 'story' and, for me, did this quite nicely with subtle metaphors and imagery. Different people will experience this game differently, if you want a game that is just about the action or puzzles, this might disappoint, but I found it to be an incredibly chilled out game, you can't die and the music is very well done, fitting the atmosphere without becoming repetative. The graphics on the trailer look really poor, but I was surprised by how nice it looked.

When I finished the game I felt like it could have been longer with more puzzles, but at the same time, I played it through in one night and it was a cool little game that kept me entertained start to finish. In some ways, the fact that it's short makes it more enjoyable.

If you can get it on sale then I recommend it, it's very different and if you can think of it loosely like paying for a film, in this case a puzzle 'experience', then it's well worth ¬£8.
Excellent. Simple but deep, lighthearted but kind of heartbreaking.
